{{Infobox education |country name = Brazil |agency image = [[Image:Flag of Brazil.svg|150px]] |agency = [[Ministry of Education (Brazil)|Ministry of Education]] |leader titles = [[Minister of Education]] |leader names = Mendonça Filho<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.planalto.gov.br/presidencia/ministros|title=Precedência|first=Portal do|last=Planalto|website=Palácio do Planalto|accessdate=29 August 2017}}</ref> |budget = 5.95% of [[GDP]]; 15.72% of total government expenditure |funding per student = |budget year = 2017 |primary languages = [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] |system type = Federal |established events = |established dates = |literacy year = |literacy total =91.73 |literacy men = |literacy women = |enroll total = |enroll primary = |enroll secondary = |enroll post-secondary = |enrollment year = |attain secondary = |attain post-secondary = |attainment year = |footnotes = }}
'''Education in Brazil''' has had many changes. Education in Brazil first began with Jesuit missions.<ref name=":7" /> They controlled education for a long time, then, two hundred years after their arrival, their powers were limited by Marquis de Pombal.<ref name=":7" /> Shortly after the Jesuits' power was limited, the Brazilian government took over education and it is now is run by the Brazilian government through the [[Ministry of Education (Brazil)|Ministry of Education]].<ref name=":7" />
Issues in education are now seen through PISA, the [[Programme for International Student Assessment]], and the Idep assessment now used by the Ministry. They have historically tested below average on all topics but are improving in mathematics.<ref name=":2" />
Brazil uses both public and private school systems. They have the traditional primary, secondary, tertiary and technical school levels.<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":5" />
==History== [[Image:Colégio Estadual Thales de Azevedo.jpg|thumb|[[Thales de Azevedo State High School]] in [[Salvador, Bahia|Salvador]]]] [[Image:Universidade Federal do Parana 3 Curitiba Parana.jpg|thumb|right|Federal University of Paraná in [[Curitiba]].]] [[Image:Faculdade medicina usp.jpg|thumb|right|Medicine College of São Paulo.]] {{See also|Society of Jesus|Education in Portugal|Colonization of the Americas}} When [[Kingdom of Portugal]]'s explorers arrived in Brazil in the 15th century and started to colonize their new possessions in the [[New World]], the territory was inhabited by [[Indigenous peoples of Brazil|indigenous peoples and tribes]] who had no writing system or school education.
The [[Society of Jesus]] (Jesuits) was, since its beginnings in 1540, a [[missionary order]]. [[Evangelisation]] was one of the main goals of the Jesuits and they were committed to teaching and education, in Europe and overseas. The missionary activities, in the cities and in the countryside, were complemented by a strong commitment to [[Education in Portugal|education]]. This took the form of the opening of schools for boys, first in Europe but rapidly extended to America and Asia. The foundation of [[Mission (Christian)|Catholic mission]]s, schools, and [[seminary|seminaries]] was another consequence of the Jesuit involvement in education. As the spaces and cultures where the Jesuits were present varied considerably, their evangelising methods were very often quite different from one place to another. However, the society's engagement in trade, architecture, science, literature, languages, arts, music and religious debate corresponded to the same main purpose of Christianisation. By the middle of the 16th century the Jesuits were present in West Africa, South America, Ethiopia, India, China, and Japan. This enlargement of their missionary activities took shape to a large extent within the framework of the [[Portuguese Empire]].
In a period when the world had a largely illiterate population, the Portuguese Empire was home to one of the first universities founded in Europe — the [[University of Coimbra]], which is one of the oldest universities in continuous operation. Throughout the centuries of Portuguese rule, Brazilian students, mostly graduated of the Jesuit missions and seminaries, were allowed and even encouraged to enroll at [[higher education in Portugal|higher education]] in [[mainland Portugal]]. [[Image:Faculdade direitoSP1.jpg|thumb|left|College of Law.]] The Jesuits, a religious order founded to promote the cause and teachings of [[Catholicism]], had gained influence with the [[Portuguese crown]] and over education, and had begun missionary work in Portugal's overseas possessions, including the colony of Brazil. By 1700, and reflecting a larger transformation of the [[Portuguese Empire]], the Jesuits had decisively shifted from the [[East Indies]] to Brazil. In the late 18th century, Portuguese minister of the kingdom [[Marquis of Pombal]] attacked the power of the privileged nobility and the church, and expelled the Jesuits from Portugal and its overseas possessions. Pombal seized the Jesuit schools and introduced education reforms all over the empire.<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=https://library.brown.edu/create/fivecenturiesofchange/chapters/chapter-2/the-jesuits/|title=The Jesuit Order in Colonial Brazil {{!}} Brazil: Five Centuries of Change|website=library.brown.edu|access-date=2018-04-11}}</ref> In Brazil, the reforms were noted.
In 1772, before the establishment of the [[Science Academy of Lisbon]] (1779), one of the first learned societies of Brazil and the Portuguese Empire was founded in [[Rio de Janeiro]]: the Sociedade Scientifica. In 1797, the first botanic institute was founded in [[Salvador, Brazil|Salvador]], [[Bahia]]. During the late 18th century, the Escola Politécnica (Polytechnic School) was created, then the Real Academia de Artilharia, Fortificação e Desenho (Royal Academy for Artillery, Fortifications and Design) was created in Rio de Janeiro, 1792, through a decree issued by the Portuguese authorities as a higher education school for the teaching of the sciences and engineering. Its legacy is shared by the [[Instituto Militar de Engenharia]] (Military Engineering Institute) and the Escola Politécnica da Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (Polytechnic School of the [[Federal University of Rio de Janeiro]]) — the oldest engineering school of Brazil and one of the oldest in the world.
A royal letter of November 20, 1800 by the King [[John VI of Portugal]] established the Aula Prática de Desenho e Figura (Practice Class for Design and Form) in [[Rio de Janeiro]]. It was the first institution in Brazil systematically dedicated to teaching the arts. During [[Colonial Brazil|colonial times]], the arts were mainly religious or utilitarian and were learnt in a system of [[apprenticeship]]. A decree on August 12, 1816 created the Escola Real de Ciências, Artes e Ofícios (Royal School of Sciences, Arts and Crafts), which established an official education in the fine arts and built the foundations of the current [[Escola Nacional de Belas Artes]] (School of Fine Arts). [[Image:EscolaMusica-UFRJ-1.jpg|thumb|right|Music school of Federal University of Rio de Janeiro.]] In the 19th century, the Portuguese royal family, headed by [[John VI of Portugal|D. João VI]], arrived in Rio de Janeiro, escaping from the [[Napoleon]]'s army invasion of Portugal in 1807. D. João VI gave impetus to the expansion of European civilization to Brazil. In the short period between 1808 and 1810, the [[Portuguese government]] founded the Academia Real dos Guarda Marinha (Royal Naval Academy), the Real Academia Militar (Royal Military Academy), the Biblioteca Nacional ([[National Library of Brazil]]), the Jardim Botânico do Rio de Janeiro ([[Rio de Janeiro Botanical Garden]]), the Academia Médico-Cirúrgica da [[Bahia]] (Medic-Cirurgical Academy of Bahia), now known as Faculdade de Medicina (Med School) in the Universidade Federal da Bahia ([[Federal University of Bahia]]) and the Academia Médico-Cirúrgica do Rio de Janeiro (Medic-Cirurgical Academy of Rio de Janeiro) which is now the medical school of the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro.
Brazil achieved [[Independence of Brazil|independence in 1822]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://library.brown.edu/create/fivecenturiesofchange/chapters/chapter-3/pedro-i-and-pedro-ii/|title=Pedro I and Pedro II {{!}} Brazil: Five Centuries of Change|website=library.brown.edu|access-date=2018-04-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=The Brazil Reader|last=Crocitti|first=John J.|last2=LeVine|first2=Robert A.|publisher=Duke University Press|year=1999|isbn=|location=Durham|pages=}}</ref> Until the 20th century, it was a large rural nation with low social and economic standards comparing to the average North American and European standards. Its economy was based on the [[primary sector]], possessing an unskilled and increasingly larger workforce, composed of free people (including slave owners) and [[Slavery in Brazil|slaves]] or their direct descendants. Among the first [[law school]]s founded in Brazil were the ones in [[Recife]] and [[São Paulo]] in 1827. But for decades to come, most Brazilian lawyers studied at European universities, such as in the ancient [[University of Coimbra]], in Portugal, which had awarded degrees to generations of Brazilian students since the 16th century.
In 1872 there were 9,930,478 inhabitants (84.8% free and 15.2% slave). According to the national census made in this year, among the free inhabitants (8,419,672 people), 38% were white, 39% mulattoes (white and black mix), 11% black and 5% caboclos (white and Indian mix). Only 23.4% of the free men and 13.4% of the free women could read and write. In 1889, six decades after independence, only 20% of the total population could read and write. In the former colonial power, Portugal, about 80% of the population was classified as illiterate.
With the massive [[Economic history of Brazil|post-war expansion]] that lasts to date, the government focused on strengthening Brazil's [[tertiary education]], while simultaneously neglecting assistance to primary and secondary education.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mre.gov.br/cdbrasil/itamaraty/web/port/polsoc/educa/apresent/apresent.htm|title=Educação|website=Mre.gov.br|accessdate=2017-08-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061128080411/http://www.mre.gov.br/CDBRASIL/ITAMARATY/WEB/port/polsoc/educa/apresent/apresent.htm|archive-date=2006-11-28|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The problems of primary and secondary education were compounded by significant quality differences across regions, with the northeast suffering dramatically.<ref>Ralph Harbison and [[Eric Hanushek]], ''Educational performance of the poor: lessons from rural northeast Brazil'' (New York: Oxford University Press, 1992).</ref> In the aftermath of [[Brazilian military government|Brazilian military rule]], education became seen as a way to create a fairer society. "Citizen schools" emerged, designed to promote critical thinking, incorporation of marginalized people, and curiosity (over rote memorization and obedience).<ref>Ignoramuses Academy, 2016</ref>
Today, Brazil struggles to improve the public education offered at earlier stages and maintain the high standards that the population has come to expect from public universities. The choice on public funding is an issue. In particular, the [[Millennium Development Goals|U.N. Development Goal]] of [[Universal Primary Education]] and a larger offer of [[Special education|education for students with special needs]] are pursued by Brazilian policy-makers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://portal.mec.gov.br/seesp/arquivos/pdf/plano1.pdf|title=Plano Nacional de Educação Especial - Ministry of Education|website=Portal.mec.gov.br|accessdate=2017-08-29}}</ref>
Despite its shortcomings, Brazil has progressed substantially since the 1980s. The nation witnessed an increase in school enrollment for children age 7–14, from 80.9% in 1980 to 96.4% in the year 2000. In the 15-17 age demographic, in the same period, this rate rose from 49.7% to 83%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.edudatabrasil.inep.gov.br/|title=Edudata Brasil|website=Edudatabrasil.inep.gov.br|accessdate=2017-08-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061224064700/http://www.edudatabrasil.inep.gov.br/|archive-date=2006-12-24|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Literacy rates rose from 75% to 90.0%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ipea.gov.br/pub/td/td_99/td_639.pdf|format=PDF|title=COELHO DE SOUZA, Marcos Medeiros. ''O Analfabetismo no Brasil sob o Enfoque Demográfico''|website=Ipea.gov.br|accessdate=2017-08-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061128044036/http://www.ipea.gov.br/pub/td/td_99/td_639.pdf|archive-date=2006-11-28|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name=IBGE>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibge.gov.br/ibgeteen/pesquisas/educacao.html|title=IBGE|website=Ibge.gov.br|accessdate=2017-08-29}}</ref> [[File:Constituição 1824 f 04.tif|thumb|213x213px|Constitution of 1824]] Voting has been mandatory for all citizens of Brazil since the first [http://pdba.georgetown.edu/Constitutions/Brazil/brazil.html Constitution of 1824]. However, people who are illiterate have, historically, not been able to be registered to vote.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://pdba.georgetown.edu/Constitutions/Brazil/brazil.htm|title=Republica Federativa do Brasil/Federative Republic of Brazil: Constituições/Constitutions.|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=March 2018}}{{dead link|date=November 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Brazil_2014.pdf|title=Brazil’s Constitution of 1988 with Amendments through 2014|last=Rosenn|first=Keith S.|date=17 January 2018|website=|access-date=}}</ref> The [[Constitution of Brazil|Constitution of 1988]] changed this, stating that those who are illiterate have the option to vote but it is not compulsory for those.<ref name=":0" /> The Constitution of 1824 also stated that those who made less than 100,000 reis were not able to vote.<ref name=":0" />
Throughout the 20th century, in response to campaigns occurring in other Latinoamérican countries, Brazilian states began their own literacy campaigns.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Paulo Freire & the Cold War Politics of Literacy|last=Kirkendall|first=Andrew J.|publisher=The University of North Carolina Press|year=2010|isbn=|location=Chapel Hill, North Carolina|pages=}}</ref> Led by educators like [[Paulo Freire]], the campaigns hoped to combat the high amounts of illiteracy in the countryside. Beginning in 1963, the campaigns were centered in rural areas.<ref name=":1" /> Paulo Freire’s methods were widely popular due to the immediacy in which they seemed to work: as he claimed, a student could learn to read and write in 40 hours.<ref name=":1" /> The growing fear of [[communism]] and the rising power of the military led to the end of the campaigns in 1964 and the exile of Freire and others like him.<ref name=":1" /> The [[Brazilian military regime|military government]] began new campaigns in the late 1970s to questionable improvements.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/10/20/weekinreview/education-watch-illiteracy-resists-treatment-in-brazil.html|title=ILLITERACY RESISTS TREATMENT IN BRAZIL|last=Riding|first=Alan|date=1985|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Issues == According to PISA, the [[Programme for International Student Assessment]], Brazil, on average, underperforms. Brazilian students score lower than the average in reading, mathematics, and science, the three categories of testing.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.compareyourcountry.org/pisa/country/BRA|title=Brazil|last=|first=|date=|website=PISA 2015.|access-date=28 March 2018}}</ref> Their scores have improved since 2000, the first year the test was taken.<ref name=":2" /> Since 2000, Brazil has started the [[Brazil Literate Program]] to lower the rate of illiteracy in those ages 15 and older.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://portal.mec.gov.br/programa-brasil-alfabetizado|title=Brazil Literate Program|last=|first=|date=|website=MInistry of Education|access-date=28 March 2018}}</ref> Brazil has also implemented the IDEP, the [[Index of Basic Education Development]], which evaluates school flow and performance rates in the test.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://portal.inep.gov.br/ideb|title=Ideb|last=|first=|date=20 October 2015|website=INEP|access-date=28 March 2018}}</ref> According to the website, the index is used to tell whether the educational system should be improved.<ref name=":3" /> The program is important in deciding public policy of the educational system.<ref name=":3" /> IDEP also led to the creation of the [[Mass mobilization|Social Mobilisation]] program which works to involve the entire community in the educational system.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mse.mec.gov.br/index.php/92-destaque-principal/destaque/164-o-que-e-mobilizacao-social-pela-educacao|title=Social Mobilization for Education|last=|first=|date=2009|website=Ministry of Education|access-date=28 March 2018}}</ref> Several other committees have created programs in individual municipalities in order to curb the IDEP findings.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=UNESCO|first=|date=2008|title=Youth and Adult Literacy in Brazil: Learning from Practice|url=|journal=|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
It takes an extra three years to finish elementary school for low-income students, [http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/993851468014439962/pdf/656590REPLACEM0hieving0World0Class0.pdf PNAD], the national household survey, shows.<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|title=Achieving World-Class Education in Brazil: The Next Agenda|last=Bruns|first=Barbara|last2=Evans|first2=David|last3=Luque|first3=Javier|publisher=The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development|year=2012|isbn=|location=Washington D.C.|pages=}}</ref> Costs of finishing school rise each year until it is impossible to attend, meaning that low-income students also have the lowest rates for completing school.<ref name=":4" /> Rio de Janeiro began a program in 2009 called the [[Reforço Escolar]] testing all students in the beginning of the school year to discover all who are not yet at grade level.<ref name=":4" /> Those who are not receive two weeks of in-depth tutoring.<ref name=":4" /> [[São Paulo]] and [[Paraná (state)|Paraná]] have also created programs to help those who are behind, either due to being low-income or for other reasons.<ref name=":4" />
== Organization and structure == [[File:Educação no Brasil.png|thumb|Table showing how the education system is organized in Brazil]] Education is divided into three levels, with grades in each level: * Pre-school education (educação infantil) is found in public institutions and private institutions. * Basic education (ensino básico) is found in public institutions and private institutions, and mandatory for those between the ages of 6 and 17.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/leis/L9394.htm|title=L9394|website=Planalto.gov.br|access-date=2016-05-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite report|url=http://portal.mec.gov.br/dmdocuments/passo_a_passo_versao_atual_16_setembro.pdf|publisher=Ministério da Educaçao (Ministry of Education)|title=Ensino fundamental de nove anos: Passo a passo do processo de implementação|trans-title=Nine years secondary school: Implementation step by step|accessdate=2017-08-29}}</ref> It consists of Elementary school (ensino fundamental) and High school (ensino médio) * Higher education (ensino superior) (including graduate degrees) is found in public institutions and private institutions.
=== Pre-school education (educação infantil) === Pre-school education is optional and exists to aid in the development of children under 6. It aims to assist in all areas of child development, including motor skills, cognitive skills, and social skills while providing fertile ground for the later acquisition of knowledge and learning. There are day nurseries for children under 2, kindergartens for 2- to 3-year-olds, and preschools for children 4 and up. Public preschools are provided by city governments.
=== Elementary school (ensino fundamental) === Elementary school is mandatory for children ages 6–14. There are nine "years" (as opposed to the former eight "grades").<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/folha/educacao/ult305u18335.shtml|title=Folha Online - Educação - Ensino fundamental de 9 anos beneficia estudantes mais pobres, diz Lula - 06/02/2006|website=Folha.uol.com.br|accessdate=2017-08-29}}</ref> The current "first year" broadly corresponds to the former pre-school last year of private institutions, and its aim is to achieve literacy. Generally speaking, the only prerequisite for enrolling in first year is that a child should be 6 years old, but some education systems allow children younger than 6 to enroll in first year (as long as they turn 6 during the first academic semester). Older students who have not completed their elementary education are allowed to attend, though those over 18 are separated from the younger children.
The National Council of Education (''Conselho Nacional de Educação'') establishes a core curriculum consisting of [[Portuguese language]], [[history]], [[geography]], [[science]], [[mathematics]], [[arts]] and [[physical education]] (for years 2, 3, 4 and 5). As for years 6, 7, 8 and 9, one or two foreign languages are also compulsory (usually English and an optional language).
Each education system supplements this core curriculum with a diversified curriculum defined by the needs of the region and the abilities of individual students.
Elementary education is divided in two stages, called ''Ensino Fundamental I'' (years 1–5) and ''Ensino Fundamental II'' (years 6–9). During ''Ensino Fundamental I'' each group of students is usually assisted by a single teacher. In ''Ensino Fundamental II'', there are as many teachers as subjects.
The length of the school year is set by the National Education Bases and Guidelines Law (''Lei de Diretrizes e Bases da Educação'') to at least 200 days. Elementary schools must provide students with at least 800 hours of activities per year. The school calendar is set by individual schools which, in rural areas, often organize their calendars according to planting and harvesting seasons.
Public elementary schools are funded by municipal and state governments. The education is similar to the British.
===High school (ensino médio){{anchor|High}}=== Students must have finished their elementary school before they enroll in high school. [[Secondary education]] takes three years. The minimum is 2,200 hours of teaching over four years. Secondary education [[core curriculum]] comprises Portuguese (including Portuguese language, essay studies, [[Brazilian literature|Brazilian]] and [[Portuguese literature]]s), foreign language (usually [[English language|English]], also [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and very rarely [[French language|French]]), [[History]], [[Geography]], [[Mathematics]], [[Physics]], [[Chemistry]] and [[Biology]]. [[Philosophy]] and [[Sociology]], which were banned during the [[Brazilian military dictatorship|military dictatorship]] (1964–1985), have become compulsory again.
High school education is provided by all levels of government.
===Technical education (ensino técnico)=== The movement of the eleventh or twelfth grade of high school or the end of those grades is mandatory for those wishing to pursue [[technical education]],<ref name=":8">{{cite web|url=http://global.britannica.com/topic/technical-education|title=Technical education|website=Britannica.com|accessdate=2017-12-02}}</ref> through courses in several areas of knowledge. In addition, students must pass a entrance examination for their specific course. These institutions usually have a greater number of hours per week. The instruction of the technical course lasts from one year and a half to two years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://agenciabrasil.ebc.com.br/educacao/noticia/2014-03/dilma-destaca-importancia-do-ensino-para-desenvolvimento-do-pais|title=Dilma destaca importância do ensino técnico para desenvolvimento do país|website=Ebc.com.br|accessdate=2017-12-01}}</ref>
===Higher education (ensino superior)=== {{main|Universities and higher education in Brazil}} [[Image:Pracacentral.JPG|thumb|right|[[Federal University of Minas Gerais]]]] [[Image:TV-Universitária-UFRN.jpg|thumb|[[TV station in Federal University of Rio Grande do Norte]]]] The secondary education is mandatory for those wishing to pursue [[higher education]]. In addition, students must pass a competitive entrance examination (known as ''[[vestibular]]'') for their specific course of study. The number of candidates per available place in the [[freshman]] class may be in excess of 30 or 40 to one in the not so competitive courses at the top public universities. The most competitive ones excess 80 or 150. In some courses with small number of vacancies, this number can be as high as 200 (medical school, for example).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cvu.uem.br/concorrencia.html|title=UEM/CVU - Cursos, Turnos e Vagas|website=Cvu.uem.br|accessdate=2017-08-29}}</ref>
As is the case in many nations, higher education in Brazil can be divided into [[undergraduate]] and [[graduate school|graduate]] work. In addition to providing education, universities promote research and provide separate classes to the community. The Brazilian standard for [[technology]], [[Licentiate (degree)|licentiate]] or [[Bachelor's degree|bachelor's]] degree is awarded in most areas of the [[arts]], [[humanities]], [[social sciences]], [[exact sciences]], or [[natural sciences]], and lasts two to three years for technology courses, three to four years for licenciate and bachelor's courses in general and five to six years for special bachelor's courses such as [[law]], [[architecture]], [[engineering]], [[human medicine]] and [[veterinary medicine]].
After graduation students can take postgraduate courses being these latu sensu or stricto sensu. Latu sensu graduate degrees are specializations and refinements lasting one to two years and do not confer academic title. At the end of the course the student must present a course completion work. (Example of latu sensu: MBA, specialization, medical residency, among others). Graduate degrees stricto sensu are courses that confer academic title. After graduation, the student must do a master's degree with a duration of two years and after that period present a master's thesis. If it is approved by the examining board, it will receive the master's degree. The doctorate course in Brazil is the most academic degree course. In order to study this postgraduate course it is necessary to have the title of Master. The doctorate has a duration of four years and must be unpublished. After four years of course the student will present the doctoral thesis to an assessment bank, if approved will receive the title of Doctor.
There are more than 2,600 universities in Brazil, between private and public, according to MEC. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seruniversitario.com.br/faculdade/|title=Ser Universitário - Tudo sobre o mundo universitário e estudantil!|website=Seruniversitario.com.br|accessdate=2017-08-29}}</ref> Higher vocational education is in general assumed by non-university institutions and the federal Institutions for Education, Science and Technology (38 in 2008).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unevoc.unesco.org/worldtvetdatabase1.php?ct=BRA|title=UNESCO-UNEVOC World TVET Database|website=Unevoc.unesco.org|accessdate=2017-08-29}}</ref>
==Teacher training and qualification== Students can obtain teacher training in secondary schools through vocational programs.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=2006|title=Brazil|url=file:///C:/Users/kenne/Downloads/Brazil_datos2006.pdf|journal=World Data on Education|volume=6|pages=|via=|access-date=2018-09-16|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130812155911/http://c/|archive-date=2013-08-12|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> In addition to the required courses to graduate, students take [[Teacher-training|teacher training]] courses which includes a supervised internship and need 300 hours of teaching practice.<ref name=":5" /> Students can be certified through the secondary school program; however, to teach [[secondary school]]s, most teaching students need higher education to obtain either a master’s or doctorate’s.<ref name=":5" /> Schools do offer school administration training, but it is not compulsory for students hoping to become an administrator.<ref name=":5" /> The licenses and degrees are as follows: teaching certification through [[vocational programs]], a bachelor’s, master’s, and doctorate.<ref name=":5" /> Recently, the government has released a new [[National Education Plan]] outlining 20 goals to improve national education, four of which outline improvements to teacher training.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://porvir.org/en/challenges-paths-teacher-training-brazil/|title=Challenges and Paths for Teacher Training in Brazil|last=Lopes|first=Marina|date=15 October 2015|website=Porvir|access-date=28 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://pne.mec.gov.br/images/pdf/pne_conhecendo_20_metas.pdf|title=Planejando a Próxima Década: Conhecendo as 20 Metas Do Plano Nacional De Educação|last=|first=|date=2014|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
==Educational statistics== [[Image:Humboldt Shule1.jpg|thumb|right|Private German school in [[São Paulo]].]] As a large middle-income country, Brazil has several regions. Its education system is accordingly plagued by many deficiencies and social and regional disparities.<ref name="IBGE"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unb.br/acs/unbagencia/ag0504-16.htm|title=Universidade de Brasília - Assessoria de Comunicação|website=Unb.br|accessdate=2017-08-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070104030828/http://www.unb.br/acs/unbagencia/ag0504-16.htm|archive-date=2007-01-04|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.missaocrianca.org.br/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=251&Itemid=2|title=Política Educacional - O Desafio da Qualidade|website=Missaocrianca.org.br|accessdate=2017-08-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070331004314/http://www.missaocrianca.org.br/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=251&Itemid=2|archive-date=2007-03-31|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>[http://www.brasilnordeste.com.br/Artigosenot%C3%ADcias/Not%C3%ADcias/Educa%C3%A7%C3%A3o/Gerenciador/tabid/105/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/1996/CampanhapropeinvestimentodemaisR24biporanoemeducao.aspx] </ref>
As of 2014: *Literacy rate of 91.73% for people age 15 or older<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=http://uis.unesco.org/country/BR|title=Brazil|last=|first=|date=|website=UNESCO|access-date=}}</ref> As of 2014: *The nation invests 5.95% of GDP on education, approximately 15.72% of total government expenditures.<ref name=":6" />
As of 2014:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://educacao.uol.com.br/atualidades/pnad-2008.jhtm#direto-ponto|title=Pnad 2008 - Atualidades - UOL Educação|website=Mre.gov.br|accessdate=2017-08-29}}</ref> *Literacy rate of 99.8% for people age 6 to 14 *Literacy rate of 90.1% for people age 15 to 17 *Literacy rate of 94.6% of Brazil.
PISA results as of 2015:
* Science: Below average; stable since 2006 * Mathematics: Below average; improvement since 2006 * Reading: Below average; stable since 2006 * Equity: ** Boys versus Girls: Above average; stable since 2006 ** Social Background: Average; improvement since 2006<ref name=":2" />
==International education== As of January 2015, the International Schools Consultancy (ISC)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iscresearch.com/|title=Home - International School Consultancy|website=Iscresearch.com|accessdate=2017-08-29}}</ref> listed Brazil as having 136 international schools.<ref name="iscresearch.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.iscresearch.com/information/isc-news.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-02-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304000123/http://www.iscresearch.com/information/isc-news.aspx |archivedate=2016-03-04 |df= }}</ref> ISC defines an 'international school' in the following terms: "ISC includes an international school if the school delivers a curriculum to any combination of pre-school, primary or secondary students, wholly or partly in English outside an English-speaking country, or if a school in a country where English is one of the official languages, offers an English-medium curriculum other than the country’s national curriculum and is international in its orientation."<ref name="iscresearch.com"/> This definition is used by publications including ''[[The Economist]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/news/international/21636757-english-language-schools-once-aimed-expatriates-now-cater-domestic-elites-new|title=The new local|website=The Economist|accessdate=2017-08-29}}</ref>

{{lead too long|date=October 2013}}
'''Educational neuroscience''' (or '''neuroeducation''',<ref>[http://www.dana.org/news/Brainwork/detail.aspx?id=22372 "Neuroeducation" Emerges as Insights into Brain Development, Learning Abilities Grow], Dana Foundation.</ref> a component of '''Mind Brain and Education''') is an emerging [[science|scientific]] field that brings together researchers in [[cognitive neuroscience]], [[developmental cognitive neuroscience]], [[educational psychology]], [[educational technology]], [[education theory]] and other related disciplines to explore the interactions between biological processes and education.<ref name = AnsariCoch>{{cite journal | last1 = Ansari | first1 = D | authorlink1 = | last2 = Coch | first2 = D | year = 2006 | title = Bridges over troubled waters: Education and cognitive neuroscience | journal = Trends in Cognitive Sciences | volume = 10 | issue = 4 | pages = 146–151 | publisher = Elsevier Science | doi = 10.1016/j.tics.2006.02.007 | pmid = 16530462}}</ref><ref name = CochAnsari>{{cite journal | last1 = Coch | first1 = D | authorlink1 = | last2 = Ansari | first2 = D | year = 2008 | title = Thinking about mechanisms is crucial to connecting neuroscience and education | journal = Cortex | volume = 45 | issue = 4 | pages = 546–547 | publisher = Elsevier Science | doi = 10.1016/j.cortex.2008.06.001 | pmid = 18649878}}</ref><ref name = Goswami2006>{{cite journal | last1 = Goswami | first1 = U | year = 2006 | authorlink1 = | title = Neuroscience and education: from research to practice? | journal = Nature Reviews Neuroscience | volume = 7 | issue = 5 | pages = 406–411 | publisher = Nature Publishing Group | doi = 10.1038/nrn1907 | pmid = 16607400}}</ref><ref name = MeltzoffScience09>{{cite journal | last1 = Meltzoff | first1 = AN | authorlink1 = | last2 = Kuhl | first2 = PK |last3 = Movellan | first3 = J | last4 = Sejnowski |first4 = TJ | year = 2009 | title = Foundations for a New Science of Learning | journal = Science | volume = 325 | issue = 5938 | pages = 284–288 | publisher = AAAS | doi = 10.1126/science.1175626 | pmc = 2776823 | pmid = 19608908}}</ref> Researchers in educational neuroscience investigate the [[neural]] mechanisms of [[Reading (process)|reading]],<ref name = Goswami2006 /> [[numerical cognition]],<ref name = AnsariNRN08>{{cite journal | last1 = Ansari | first1 = D | authorlink1 = | year = 2008 | title = Effects of development and enculturation on number representation in the brain | journal = Nature Reviews Neuroscience| volume = 9 | issue = 4 | pages = 278–291 | publisher = Nature Publishing Group | doi = 10.1038/nrn2334 | pmid = 18334999}}</ref> [[attention]] and their attendant difficulties including [[dyslexia]],<ref name = McCandlissNoble>{{cite journal | last1 = McCandliss| first1 = BD | authorlink1 = | last2 = Noble | first2 = KG | year = 2003 | title = The development of reading impairment: a cognitive neuroscience model | journal = Mental Retardation and Developmental Disability Research Review | volume = 9 | issue = 3 | pages = 196–204 | publisher = | doi = 10.1002/mrdd.10080| pmid = 12953299}}</ref><ref name = GabrieliScience09>{{cite journal | last1 = Gabrieli | first1 = JD | year = 2009 | authorlink1 = | title = Dyslexia: a new synergy between education and cognitive neuroscience | journal = Science | volume = 325 | issue = 5938 | pages = 280–283 | publisher = AAAS | doi = 10.1126/science.1171999 | pmid = 19608907}}</ref> [[dyscalculia]]<ref name = Price2007>{{cite journal | last1 = Price | first1 = GR | last2 = Holloway | first2 = I | last3 = Räsänen | first3 = P | last4 = Vesterinen | first4 = M | last5 = Ansari | first5 = D | year = 2007 | title = Impaired parietal magnitude processing in developmental dyscalculia | journal = Current Biology | publisher = Cell Press | volume = 17 | issue = 24 | pages = R1042–1043 | doi = 10.1016/j.cub.2007.10.013 | pmid = 18088583}}</ref> and [[ADHD]] as they relate to [[education]]. Researchers in this area may link basic findings in cognitive neuroscience with educational technology to help in [[curriculum]] implementation for [[mathematics education]] and [[reading education]]. The aim of educational neuroscience is to generate [[basic research|basic]] and [[applied research]] that will provide a new transdisciplinary account of [[learning]] and [[teaching]], which is capable of informing education. A major goal of educational neuroscience is to bridge the gap between the two fields through a direct dialogue between researchers and educators, avoiding the "middlemen of the brain-based learning industry". These middlemen have a vested commercial interest in the selling of "neuromyths" and their supposed remedies.<ref name = Goswami2006 />
The potential of educational neuroscience has received varying degrees of support from both cognitive neuroscientists and educators. Davis<ref name = Davis04>{{cite journal | last1 = Davis | first1 = A | year = 2004 | title = The credentials of brain-based learning | journal = Journal of the Philosophy of Education | volume = 38 | issue = 1 | pages = 21–36 | publisher = Wiley Interscience | doi = 10.1111/j.0309-8249.2004.00361.x}}</ref> argues that medical models of cognition, "...have only a very limited role in the broader field of education and learning mainly because learning-related intentional states are not internal to individuals in a way which can be examined by brain activity". Pettito and Dunbar<ref name = PetittoDunbar04>{{cite conference | last1 = Petitto | first1 = LA | last2 = Dunbar | first2 = K | year = 2004 | title = New findings from educational neuroscience on bilingual brains, scientific brains, and the educated mind. | editor1-last = Fischer | editor1-first = K | editor2-last = Katzir | editor2-first = T | booktitle = Building Usable Knowledge in Mind, Brain, & Education | publisher = Cambridge University Press}}</ref> on the other hand, suggest that educational neuroscience "provides the most relevant level of analysis for resolving today’s core problems in education". Howard-Jones and Pickering<ref name = DfESReport>{{Cite journal | last1 = Howard-Jones | first1 = P |last2 = Pickering | first2 = S. |last3 = Diack | first3 = A | year = 2007 | title = Perception of the role of neuroscience in education. Summary Report for the DfES Innovation Unit | postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref> surveyed the opinions of teachers and educators on the topic, and found that they were generally enthusiastic about the use of neuroscientific findings in the field of education, and that they felt these findings would be more likely to influence their teaching methodology than curriculum content. Some researchers take an intermediate view and feel that a direct link from neuroscience to education is a "bridge too far",<ref name=Bruer1997>{{cite journal | last = Bruer | first = JT | year = 1997 | title = Education and the brain: A bridge too far | journal = Educational Researcher | volume = 26 | pages = 4–16 | doi=10.3102/0013189x026008004}}</ref> but that a bridging discipline, such as cognitive psychology or educational psychology<ref name = Mason2009>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/j.cortex.2008.06.003 | last = Mason | first = L. |year = 2009 | title = Bridging neuroscience and education: A two-way path is possible | journal = Cortex | publisher = Elsevier Science | volume = 45 | issue = 4 | pages = 548–549 | pmid = 18632093}}</ref> can provide a neuroscientific basis for educational practice. The prevailing opinion, however, appears to be that the link between education and neuroscience has yet to realise its full potential, and whether through a third research discipline, or through the development of new neuroscience research paradigms and projects, the time is right to apply neuroscientific research findings to education in a practically meaningful way.<ref name = AnsariCoch /><ref name = Goswami2006 /><ref name = MeltzoffScience09 />
Several academic institutions around the world are beginning to devote resources and energy to the establishment of research centres focused on educational neuroscience research. For example, the Centre for Educational Neuroscience in London UK is an inter-institutional project between [[University College, London]], [[Birkbeck, University of London|Birkbeck]] and the [[Institute of Education]]. The centre brings together researchers with expertise in the fields of emotional, conceptual, attentional, language and mathematical development, as well as specialists in education and learning research with the aim of building a new scientific discipline (Educational Neuroscience) in order to ultimately promote better learning.
==The need for a new discipline== The emergence of educational neuroscience has been born out of the need for a new discipline that makes scientific research practically applicable in an educational context. Addressing the broader field of "mind, brain and education", Kurt Fischer states, "The traditional model will not work. It is not enough for researchers to collect data in schools and make those data and the resulting research papers available to educators",<ref name = Fischer2009>{{cite journal | last = Fischer | first = KW | year = 2009 | title = Mind, Brain, and Education:Building a scientific groundwork for learning and teaching | journal = Mind, Brain and Education | publisher = Wiley Periodicals | volume = 3 | issue = 1 | pages = 3–16 | url = http://gseweb.harvard.edu/~ddl/articlesCopy/FischerGroundwork.MBE2009.3.1.pdf | doi = 10.1111/j.1751-228X.2008.01048.x}}</ref> as this method excludes teachers and learners from contributing to the formation of appropriate research methods and questions.
Learning in cognitive psychology and neuroscience has focused on how individual humans and other species have evolved to extract useful information from the natural and social worlds around them.<ref name = Frith2007>{{cite book | last = Frith |first = C | year = 2007 | title = Making Up the Mind: How the Brain Creates Our Mental World |publisher = Oxford: Blackwell | isbn = 978-1-4051-6022-3}}</ref> By contrast, education, and especially modern formal education, focuses on descriptions and explanations of the world that learners cannot be expected to acquire by themselves. In this way, learning in the scientific sense, and learning in the educational sense can be seen as complementary concepts. This creates a new challenge for cognitive neuroscience to adapt to the real world practical requirements of educational learning. Conversely, neuroscience creates a new challenge for education, because it provides new characterizations of the current state of the learner – including brain state, genetic state, and hormonal state - that could be relevant to learning and teaching. By providing new measures of the effects of learning and teaching, including brain structure and activity, it is possible to discriminate different types of learning method and attainment. For example, neuroscience research can already distinguish learning by rote from learning through conceptual understanding in mathematics.<ref name = Ischebeck2006>{{cite journal | last1 = Ischebeck | first1 = A. | last2 = Zamarian | year = 2006 | first2 = L | last3 = Siedentopf | first3 = C | last4 = Koppelstätter | first4 = F | last5 = Benke | first5 = T | last6 = Felber | first6 = S | last7 = Delazer | first7 = M | title = How specifically do we learn? Imaging the learning of multiplication and subtraction | journal = NeuroImage | publisher = Elsevier | volume = 30 | issue = 4 | pages = 1365–1375 | pmid = 16413795 |doi = 10.1016/j.neuroimage.2005.11.016}}</ref>
The [[United States National Academy of Sciences]] published an important report, stressing that, "Neuroscience has advanced to the point where it is time to think critically about the form in which research information is made available to educators so that it is interpreted appropriately for practice—identifying which research findings are ready for implementation and which are not."<ref name = HowPeopleLearn>{{cite book | last1 = Bransford | first1 = JD | last2 = Brown | first2 = AL | last3 = Cocking |first3 = RR | year = 2000 | title = How people learn : brain, mind, experience, and school (Expanded edition) | url = http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=6160 | publisher = Washington, DC: National Academy of Sciences: Committee on Developments in the Science of Learning and Committee on Learning Research and Educational Practice | isbn = 0-309-07036-8}}</ref>
In their book ''The Learning Brain'', researchers from London’s "Centre for Educational Neuroscience", Blakemore & Frith outline the developmental neurophysiology of the human brain that has given rise to many theories regarding educational neuroscience.<ref name = BlakemoreFrithPrecis>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1111/j.1467-7687.2005.00434.x | last1 = Blakemore |first1 = SJ |last2 = Frith |first2 = U |year = 2005 |title = The learning brain: lessons for education: a precis |journal = Developmental Science | volume = 8 | issue = 6 | pages = 459–465 | pmid = 16246234}}</ref> One of the fundamental pillars supporting the link between education and neuroscience is the ability of the brain to learn. Neuroscience is developing and increasing our understanding of early brain development, and how these brain changes might relate to learning processes.
==Early brain development== {{main|Neural development}}
Almost all of the neurons in the brain are generated before birth, during the first three months of pregnancy, and the newborn child’s brain has a similar number of neurons to that of an adult. Many more neurons form than are needed, and only those that form active connections with other neurons survive. In the first year after birth the infant brain undergoes an intense phase of development, during which excessive numbers of connections between neurons are formed, and many of these excess connections must be cut back through the process of [[synaptic pruning]] that follows. This pruning process is just as important a stage of development as the early rapid growth of connections between brain cells. The process during which large numbers of connections between neurons are formed is called [[synaptogenesis]]. For vision and hearing (visual and auditory cortex), there is extensive early synaptogenesis. The density of connections peaks at around 150% of adult levels between four and 12 months, and the connections are then extensively pruned. Synaptic density returns to adult levels between two and four years in the visual cortex. For other areas such as prefrontal cortex (thought to underpin planning and reasoning), density increases more slowly and peaks after the first year. Reduction to adult levels of density takes at least another 10–20 years; hence there is significant brain development in the frontal areas even in adolescence. Brain metabolism (glucose uptake, which is an approximate index of synaptic functioning) is also above adult levels in the early years. Glucose uptake peaks at about 150% of adult levels somewhere around four to five years. By the age of around ten years, brain metabolism has reduced to adult levels for most cortical regions. Brain development consists of bursts of synaptogenesis, peaks of density, and then synapse rearrangement and stabilisation. This occurs at different times and different rates for different brain regions, which implies that there may be different sensitive periods for the development of different types of knowledge. Neuroscience research into early brain development has informed government education policy for children under three years old in many countries including the USA and the United Kingdom. These policies have focused on enriching the environment of children during nursery and preschool years, exposing them to stimuli and experiences thought to maximise the learning potential of the young brain.
==Can neuroscience inform education?== Although an increasing number of researchers are seeking to establish educational neuroscience as a productive field of research, debate still continues with regards to the potential for practical collaboration between the fields of neuroscience and education, and whether neuroscientific research really has anything to offer educators.
Daniel Willingham<ref name = Willingham2009>{{cite journal | last = Willingham |first = DT |year = 2009 |title = Three problems in the marriage of neuroscience and education | journal = Cortex | publisher = Elsevier Science | volume = 45 |issue = 4 | pages = 544–545 | doi = 10.1016/j.cortex.2008.05.009 | pmid = 18644588 }}</ref> states that "whether neuroscience can be informative to educational theory and practice is not debatable-it has been." He draws attention to the fact that behavioural research alone was not decisive in determining whether developmental dyslexia was a disorder of primarily visual or phonological origin. Neuroimaging research was able to reveal reduced activation for children with dyslexia in brain regions known to support phonological processing,<ref name =Rumsey1992>{{cite journal | last1 = Rumsey |first1 = JM | last2 = Andreason | first2 = P | last3 = Zametkin | first3 = AJ | last4 = Aquino | first4 = T | last5 = King | first5 = AC | last6 = Hamburger | first6 = SD | last7 = Pikus | first7 = A | last8 = Rapoport | first8 = JL | last9 = Cohen | first9 = RM <!--exactly 9 authors--> | year = 1992 | title = Failure to activate the left temporoparietal cortex in dyslexia: An oxygen 15 positron emission tomographic study | journal = Archives of Neurology | volume = 49 | issue = 5 |pages = 527–534 | pmid = 1580816 | doi = 10.1001/archneur.1992.00530290115020}}</ref> thus supporting behavioural evidence for the phonological theory of dyslexia.
While John Bruer<ref name = Bruer1997 /> suggests that the link between neuroscience and education is essentially impossible without a third field of research to link the two, other researchers feel that this view is too pessimistic. While acknowledging that more bridges must be built between basic neuroscience and education, and that so called neuromyths (see below) must be deconstructed, Usha Goswami<ref name = Goswami2004>{{cite journal | last1 = Goswami | first1 = U | year = 2004 | title = Neuroscience and education | pages = 1–14 | journal = British Journal of Educational Psychology |volume = 74 | issue = 1 | doi = 10.1348/000709904322848798 | pmid = 15096296}}</ref> suggests that cognitive developmental neuroscience has already made several discoveries of use to education, and has also led to the discovery of ‘neural markers’ that can be used to assess development. In other words, milestones of neural activity or structure are being established, against which an individual can be compared in order to assess their development.
For example, [[event-related potential]] (ERP) research has uncovered several neural signatures of language processing, including markers of semantic processing (e.g. N400), phonetic processing (e.g. mismatch negativity) and syntactic processing (e.g. P600). Goswami<ref name = Goswami2004 /> points out that these parameters can now be investigated longitudinally in children, and that certain patterns of change may indicate certain developmental disorders. Furthermore, the response of these neural markers to focused educational interventions may be used as a measure of the intervention’s effectiveness. Researchers such as Goswami assert that cognitive neuroscience has the potential to offer various exciting possibilities to education. For special education, these include the early diagnosis of special educational needs; the monitoring and comparison of the effects of different kinds of educational input on learning; and an increased understanding of individual differences in learning and the best ways to suit input to learner.<ref name = Goswami2004 />
A potential application of neuroimaging highlighted by Goswami<ref name = Goswami2004 /> is in differentiating between delayed development and atypical development in learning disorders. For instance, is a given child with dyslexia developing reading functions in a totally different way from typical readers, or is he/she developing along the same trajectory, but just taking longer to do so? Indeed, evidence already exists to suggest that in children with specific language impairments and dyslexia the development of the language system is delayed rather than fundamentally different in nature.<ref name = McArthur2004>{{cite journal | last1 = McArthur | first1 = GM | last2 = Bishop |first2 = DVM | year = 2004 | title = Which people with specific language impairment have auditory processing deficits? |journal = Cognitive Neuropsychology | publisher = Psychology Press | pmid = 21038192 |volume = 21 |issue = 1 |pages = 79–94 | doi = 10.1080/02643290342000087}}</ref><ref name = Thomson2005>{{cite journal | last1 = Thomson |first1 = J | last2 = Baldeweg | first2 = T | last3 = Goswami |first3 = U. | year = 2005 | title = Amplitude envelope onsets and dyslexia: a behavioural and electrophysiological study | journal = ISCA}}</ref> In disorders such as autism however, brain development may be qualitatively different, showing a lack of development in brain regions associated with a "theory of mind".<ref name = Frith1998>{{cite journal | last1 = Frith | first1 = U | last2 = Happe | first2 = F | year = 1998 | title = Why specific developmental disorders are not specific: On-line and developmental effects in autism and dyslexia | journal = Developmental Science | publisher = Blackwell Publishing | volume = 1 | issue = 2 | pages = 267–272 | doi = 10.1111/1467-7687.00041}}</ref>
Goswami<ref name = Goswami2004 /> also suggests that neuroimaging could be used to assess the impact of particular training programmes, such as the Dore, an exercise based programme based on the cerebellar deficit hypothesis that aims to improve reading through a series of balance exercises. Some brain imaging research is beginning to show that for children with dyslexia who receive targeted educational interventions, their brain activation patterns begin to look more like those of people without reading disorders, and in addition, that other brain regions are acting as compensatory mechanisms.<ref name = Shaywitz2003>{{cite journal |last1 = Shaywitz |first1 = SE | last2 = Shaywitz | first2 = BA | last3 = Fulbright |first3 = RK | last4 = Skudlarski | first4 = P | last5 = Mencl |first5 = WE | last6 = Constable| first6 = RT | last7 = Pugh | first7 = KR | last8 = Holahan | first8 = JM | last9 = Marchione | first9 = KE | last10=Fletcher | first10=JM | last11=Lyon | first11=GR | last12=Gore | first12=JC | year = 2003 | title = Neural systems for compensation and persistence: Young adult outcome of childhood reading disability | journal = Biological Psychiatry | publisher = Elsevier Science | volume = 54 |pages = 25–33 | issue = 1 | doi = 10.1016/S0006-3223(02)01836-X | pmid = 12842305}}</ref><ref name = Temple2003>{{cite journal | last1 = Temple | first1 = E | last2 = Deutsch | first2 = GK | last3 = Poldrack | first3 = RA | last4 = Miller | first4 = SL | last5 = Tallal | first5 = P | last6 = Merzenich | first6 = MM | last7 = Gabrieli | first7 = JD | year = 2003 | title = Neural deficits in children with dyslexia ameliorated by behavioral remediation: Evidence from functional MRI |journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences |volume = 100 | issue = 5 |pages = 2860–2865 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0030098100 | pmc = 151431 | pmid = 12604786}}</ref> Such findings may help educators understand that, even if dyslexic children show behavioural improvement, the neural and cognitive mechanisms by which they process written information may still be different, and this may have practical implications for the ongoing instruction of these children.<ref name = Katzir2006>{{cite journal | last1 = Katzir | first1 = T | last2 = Pare-Blagoev | first2 = J | year = 2006 | title = Applying cognitive neuroscience research to education: The case of literacy | pages = 53–74 | journal = Educational Psychologist |volume = 41 | issue = 1 | doi = 10.1207/s15326985ep4101_6}}</ref>
Neuroscience research has evidenced its ability to reveal ‘neural markers’ of learning disorders, most notably in the case of dyslexia. EEG studies have revealed that human infants at risk of dyslexia (i.e. with immediate family members who suffer from dyslexia) show atypical neural responses to changes in speech sounds, even before they are able to understand the semantic content of language.<ref name = Guttorm2005>{{cite journal | last1 = Guttorm | first1 = TK | last2 = Leppänen | first2 = PH | last3 = Poikkeus | first3 = AM | last4 = Eklund | first4 = KM | last5 = Lyytinen | first5 = P | last6 = Lyytinen | first6 = H | title = Brain event-related potentials (ERPs) measured at birth predict later language development in children with and without familial risk for dyslexia | journal = Cortex | publisher = Elsevier Science | volume = 41 | issue = 3 | year = 2005 | pages = 291–303 | doi = 10.1016/S0010-9452(08)70267-3 | pmid = 15871595}}</ref> Not only does such research allow for the early identification of potential learning disorders, but it further supports the phonological hypothesis of dyslexia in a manner unavailable to behavioural research.
Many researchers advocate a cautious optimism with regards to the marriage between education and neuroscience, and believe that to bridge the gap between the two, the development of new experimental paradigms is necessary and that these new paradigms should be designed to capture the relationships between neuroscience and education across different levels of analysis (neuronal, cognitive, behavioural).<ref name = Katzir2006 />
==Neuroscience and education: Sample cases== ===Language and literacy=== {{main|Reading (process)|Dyslexia}}
Human language is a unique faculty of the mind<ref name = Pinker2005>{{cite journal | last1 = Pinker | first1 = S |last2 = Jackendoff | first2 = R | year = 2005 | title = The faculty of language: what's special about it? | journal = Cognition | publisher = Elsevier Science | volume = 95 | issue = 2 | pages = 201–236 | doi = 10.1016/j.cognition.2004.08.004 | pmid = 15694646}}</ref> and the ability to understand and produce oral and written language is fundamental to academic achievement and attainments.<ref name = Catts1999>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1207/s1532799xssr0304_2 | last1 = Catts | first1 = HW | last2 = Fey | first2 = ME | last3 = Zhang | first3 = X | last4 = Tomblin |first4 = JB | year = 1999 | title = Language basis of reading and reading disabilities: Evidence from a longitudinal investigation | journal = Scientific Studies of Reading | publisher = Lawerence Erlbaum Associates | volume = 3 | issue = 4 | pages = 331–361}}</ref> Children who experience difficulties with oral language raise significant challenges for educational policy and practice;<ref name = Bercow2008>{{Cite journal | last1 = Bercow | first1 = J | year = 2008 | title = The Bercow Report. A Review of Services for Children and Young People (0-19) With Speech, Language and Communications Needs | postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref> National Strategies, Every Child a Talker (2008). The difficulties are likely to persist during the primary school years<ref name = Tomblin2003>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1044/1092-4388(2003/100) | last1 = Tomblin | first1 = JB | last2 = Zhang | first2 = X | last3 = Buckwalter | first3 = P | last4 = O'Brien | first4 = M | year = 2003 | title = The stability of primary language disorder: Four years after kindergarten diagnosis | journal = Journal of Speech, Language, and Hearing Research | volume = 46 | issue = 6 | pages = 1283–1296 | pmid = 14700355}}</ref> where, in addition to core deficits with oral language, children experience problems with literacy,<ref name = Catts1993>{{cite journal | last1 = Catts | first1 = HW | year = 1993 | title = The relationship between speech-language impairments and reading disabilities | journal = Journal of Speech and Hearing Research | volume = 36 | issue = 5 | pages = 948–58 | pmid = 8246483}}</ref> numeracy<ref name = Donlan2007>{{cite journal | last1 = Donlan | first1 = C | last2 = Cowan | first2 = R | last3 = Newton | first3 = EJ | last4 = Lloyd | first4 = D | year = 2007 | title = The role of language in mathematical development: Evidence from children with specific language impairments | journal = Cognition | publisher = Elsevier Science | volume = 103 | issue = 1 | pages = 23–33 | pmid = 16581052 | doi = 10.1016/j.cognition.2006.02.007}}</ref> and behaviour and peer relations.<ref name = Dockrell2001>{{cite journal | last1 = Dockrell | first1 = JE | last2 = Lindsay | first2 = G | year = 2001 | title = Children with Specific Speech and Language Difficulties—the teachers perspective | journal = Oxford Review of Education | volume = 27 | issue = 3 | pages = 369–394 | doi=10.1080/03054980125168}}</ref> Early identification and intervention to address these difficulties, as well as identification of the ways in which learning environments can support atypical language development are essential.<ref name = Bercow2008 /> Untreated speech and language needs result in significant costs both to the individual and to the national economy (ICAN, 2006).
Over the last decade, there has been a significant increase in neuroscience research examining young children's processing of language at the phonetic, word, and sentence levels.<ref name = Kuhl2008>{{cite journal | last1 = Kuhl | first1 = P | last2 = Rivera-Gaxiola | first2 = M | year = 2008 | title = Neural substrates of language acquisition | url = http://ilabs.washington.edu/kuhl/pdf/Kuhl&Rivera-Gaxiola2008.pdf | journal = Annual Review of Neuroscience | volume = 31 | pages = 511–534 | pmid = 18558865 | doi = 10.1146/annurev.neuro.30.051606.094321}}</ref> There are clear indications that neural substrates for all levels of language can be identified at early points in development. At the same time, intervention studies have demonstrated the ways in which the brain retains its plasticity for language processing. Intense remediation with an auditory language processing program has been accompanied by functional changes in left temporo-parietal cortex and inferior frontal gyrus.<ref name = Temple2003 /> However, the extent to which these results generalize to spoken and written language is debated.<ref name = McArthur2008>{{cite journal | last1 = McArthur | first1 = GM | last2 = Ellis | first2 = D | last3 = Atkinson |first3 = CM | last4 = Coltheart | first4 = M | year = 2008 | title = Auditory processing deficits in children with reading and language impairments: Can they (and should they) be treated? | journal = Cognition | publisher = Elsevier Science | volume = 107 | issue = 3 | pages = 946–977 | pmid = 18262177 | doi = 10.1016/j.cognition.2007.12.005}}</ref>
The relationships between meeting the educational needs of children with language difficulties and the findings of neuroscience studies are not yet established. One concrete avenue for progress is to use neuroscientific methods to address questions that are significant to practice in learning environments. For example, the extent to which language skills are attributable to a single common trait, and the consistency of such a trait over development, are matters of debate.<ref name = Tomblin2006>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1044/1092-4388(2006/086) | last1 = Tomblin | first1 = JB | last2 = Zhang | first2 = X | year = 2006 | title = The dimensionality of language ability in school-age children | journal = Journal of Speech, Language, and Hearing Research | volume = 49 | issue = 6 | pages = 1193–1208 | pmid = 17197490}}</ref> However, direct assessments of brain activity can inform these debates.<ref name = Fontenau2008>{{cite journal | last1 = Fonteneau | first1 = E | last2 = van der Lely | first2 = HKJ | last3 = Pinker | year = 2008 | first3 = Steven | title = Electrical Brain Responses in Language-Impaired Children Reveal Grammar-Specific Deficits | url = http://www.plosone.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.pone.0001832 | pages = e1832 | journal = PLoS ONE | volume = 3 | issue = 3 | pmid = 18347740 | pmc = 2268250 | doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0001832 | editor1-last = Pinker | editor1-first = Steven}} {{open access}}</ref> A detailed understanding of the sub-components of the language system, and the ways these change over time may inevitably yield implications for educational practice.
===Mathematics=== {{Main|Numerical cognition|Mathematics education|Dyscalculia}}
Mathematical skills are important not only for the national economy but also for an individual’s life chances: low numeracy increases the probability of arrest, depression, physical illnesses, unemployment.<ref name = Parsons>{{Cite journal | last1 = Parsons | first1 = S | last2 = Bynner | first2 = J | year = 2005 | title = Does numeracy matter more? | url = http://www.nrdc.org.uk/download.asp?f=2979&e=pdf | publisher = National Research and Development Centre for Adult Literacy and Numeracy, Institute of Education, UK | postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref> One of the main causes of low numeracy is a congenital condition called dyscalculia. As the Foresight report on Mental Capital and Wellbeing puts it, "Developmental dyscalculia – because of its low profile but high impacts, its priority should be raised. Dyscalculia relates to numeracy and affects between 4-7% of children. It has a much lower profile than dyslexia but can also have substantial impacts: it can reduce lifetime earnings by £114,000 and reduce the probability of achieving five or more [[GCSE]]s (A*-C) by 7–20 percentage points. Home and school interventions have again been identified by the Project. Also, technological interventions are extremely promising, offering individualised instruction and help, although these need more development." (Executive Summary, Section 5.3) Understanding typical and atypical mathematical development is a crucial underpinning for the design of both the mainstream mathematics curriculum and for helping those who fail to keep up.<ref name = Ansari2002>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S1364-6613(02)02040-5 | last1 = Ansari | first1 = D | last2 = Karmiloff-Smith | first2 = A | year = 2002 | title = Atypical trajectories of number development: a neuroconstructivist perspective | journal = Trends in Cognitive Sciences | publisher = Cell Press | volume = 6 | pages = 511–516 | issue = 12 | pmid = 12475711}}</ref> Over the past ten years, a brain system for simple number processing has been identified<ref name = Dehaene2003>{{cite journal | last1 = Dehaene | first1 = S |last2 = Piazza |first2 = M | last3 = Pinel |first3 = P | last4 = Cohen | first4 = L | year = 2003 | title = Three parietal circuits for number processing | url = http://www.unicog.org/publications/DehaeneEtAl_3parietalCircuits_CogNeuropsy2003.pdf | journal = Cognitive Neuropsychology | publisher = Psychology Press | volume = 20 | issue = 3–6 | pages = 487–506 | doi = 10.1080/02643290244000239 | pmid=20957581}}</ref><ref name = Castelli2006>{{cite journal | last1 = Castelli | first1 = F | last2 = Glaser | first2 = DE | last3 = Butterworth | first3 = B | year = 2006 | title = Discrete and analogue quantity processing in the parietal lobe: A functional MRI study | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the USA | publisher = National Academies | volume = 103 | issue = 12 | pages = 4693–4698 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0600444103 | pmc = 1450233 | pmid = 16537401}}</ref> and a handful of studies of children’s brains that throw a little light on its development.<ref name = Price2007 />
An increasing convergence of evidence suggests that dyscalculia may be due to a deficit in an inherited core system for representing the number of objects in a set, and how operations on sets affect number<ref name = Landerl2004>{{cite journal | last1 = Landerl |first1 = K | last2 = Bevan | first2 =A | last3 = Butterworth |first3 = B | year = 2004 | title = Developmental dyscalculia and basic numerical capacities: a study of 8-9-year-old students |journal = Cognition | publisher = Elsevier Science | pages = 99–125 | volume = 93 | issue = 2 | doi = 10.1016/j.cognition.2003.11.004 | pmid = 15147931}}</ref> and in the neural systems that support these abilities.<ref name = Price2007 /> This core deficit affects the learner’s ability to enumerate sets and to order sets by magnitude, which in turn make it very difficult to understand arithmetic, and very hard to provide a meaningful structure for arithmetical facts. Twin<ref name = Alarcon1997>{{cite journal | last1 = Alarcon | first1 = M | last2 = DeFries | first2 = JC | last3 = Light | first3 = JG | last4 = Pennington | first4 = BF | year = 1997 | title = A twin study of mathematics disability | journal = Journal of Learning Disabilities | publisher = Sage Publishing | pages = 617–623 | volume = 30 | issue = 6 | doi = 10.1177/002221949703000605 | pmid = 9364899}}</ref> and family<ref name = Shalev2001>{{cite journal | last1 = Shalev | first1 = RS | last2 = Manor | first2 = O | last3 = Kerem | first3 = B | last4 = Ayali | first4 = M | last5 = Badichi | first5 = N | last6= Friedlander | first6 = Y | last7 = Gross-Tsur | first7 = V | year = 2001 | title = Developmental dyscalculia is a familial learning disability | journal = Journal of Learning Disabilities | publisher = Sage Publishing | pages = 59–65 | volume = 34 | issue = 1 | doi = 10.1177/002221940103400105 | pmid = 15497272}}</ref> studies suggest that dyscalculia is highly heritable, and genetic anomalies, such as Turner’s Syndrome, indicate an important role for genes in the X chromosome.<ref name = Mazzocco2005>{{cite conference | last1 = Mazzocco | first1 = MMM | last2 = McCloskey | first2 = M | year = 2005 | title = Math performance in girls with Turner or fragile X syndrome | pages=269–297 | editor-last = Campbell | editor-first = JID | booktitle = Handbook of Mathematical Cognition | publisher = Psychology Press | ISBN = 978-1-84169-411-5}}</ref>
This suggestion that dyscalculia is caused by a deficits in a core deficit in number sense is analogous to the theory that dyslexia is due to a core deficit in phonological processing. Despite these similarities in terms of the scientific progress, public awareness of dyscalculia is much lower than it is for dyslexia. The [[Chief Scientific Adviser to HM Government|UK's Chief Scientific Advisor]], [[John Beddington]], notes that, "developmental dyscalculia is currently the poor relation of dyslexia, with a much lower public profile. But the consequences of dyscalculia are at least as severe as those for dyslexia."<ref name = Beddington2008>{{cite journal | last1 = Beddington | first1 = J | last2 = Cooper | first2 = CL | last3 = Field | first3 = J | last4 = Goswami | first4 = U | last5 = Huppert | first5 = FA | last6 = Jenkins | first6 = R | last7 = Jones | first7 = HS | last8 = Kirkwood | first8 = TBL | last9 = Sahakian | first9 = BJ | last10=Thomas | first10=SM | year = 2008 | title = The mental wealth of nations | journal = Nature | publisher = Nature Publishing Group | volume = 455 | issue = 7216 | pages = 1057–1060 | doi = 10.1038/4551057a | pmid = 18948946}}</ref>
The application of neuroscience to understanding mathematical processing has already resulted in understanding beyond the early cognitive theories. Cognitive neuroscience research has revealed the existence of an innate ‘number sense’ system, present in animals and infants as well as adults, that is responsible for basic knowledge about numbers and their relations. This system is located in the parietal lobe of the brain in each hemisphere.<ref name = Dehaene2003 /><ref name = Dehaene1998>{{cite journal | last1 = Dehaene | first1 = S | last2 = Dehaene-Lambertz | first2 = G | last3 = Cohen | first3 = L | title = Abstract representations of numbers in the animal and human brain | url = http://www.unicog.org/publications/Dehaene_ReviewNumbersAnimalsInfants_TINS1998.pdf | journal = Trends in Neurosciences | publisher = Elsevier Science | volume = 21 | pages = 355–361 | year = 1998 | issue = 8 | doi = 10.1016/S0166-2236(98)01263-6 | pmid = 9720604}}</ref> This parietal system is active in children and adults during basic numerical tasks,<ref name = Temple1998>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1073/pnas.95.13.7836 | last1 = Temple | first1 = E | last2 = Posner | first2 = MI | year = 1998 | title = Brain mechanisms of quantity are similar in 5-year-old children and adults | url = http://www.pnas.org/content/95/13/7836.full.pdf | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the USA | volume = 95 | issue = 13 | pages = 7836–7841 | pmid = 9636237 | pmc = 22775}}</ref><ref name = Ansari2005>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1097/01.wnr.0000183905.23396.f1 | last1 = Ansari | first1 = D | last2 = Garcia | first2 = N | last3 = Lucas | first3 = E | last4 = Hamon | first4 = K | last5 = Dhital | first5 = B | year = 2005 | title = Neural correlates of symbolic number processing in children and adults | journal = NeuroReport | volume = 16 | issue = 16 | pages = 1769–1773 | pmid = 16237324}}</ref> but over the course of development it appears to become more specialised. Furthermore, children with mathematical learning disabilities (dyscalculia) show weaker activation in this region than typically developing children during basic number tasks.<ref name = Price2007 /> These results show how neuroimaging can provide important information about the links between basic cognitive functions and higher level learning, such as those between comparing two numbers and learning arithmetic.
In addition to this basic number sense, numerical information can be stored verbally in the language system, a system that neuroscience research is beginning to reveal as qualitatively different at the brain level to the number sense system.<ref name = Dehaene1999>{{cite journal | last1 = Dehaene | first1 = S | last2 = Spelke | first2 = E | last3 = Pinel | first3 = P | last4 = Stanescu | first4 = R | last5 = Tsivkin | first5 = S | year = 1999 | title = Sources of mathematical thinking: behavioral and brain-imaging evidence | url = http://www.unicog.org/publications/DehaeneSpelke_ExactApprox_Science1999.pdf | journal = Science | publisher = AAAS | volume = 284 | issue = 5416 | pages = 970–974 | doi = 10.1126/science.284.5416.970 | pmid = 10320379}}</ref> This system also stores information about other well learned verbal sequences, such as days of the week, months of the year and even poetry, and for numerical processing it supports counting and the learning of multiplication tables. While many arithmetic problems are so over learned that they are stored as verbal facts, other more complex problems require some form of visuo-spatial mental imagery.<ref name = Zago2001>{{cite journal | last1 = Zago | first1 = L | last2 = Pesenti | first2 = M | last3 = Mellet | first3 = E | last4 = Crivello | first4 = F | last5 = Mazoyer | first5 = B | last6 = Tzourio-Mazoyer | first6 = N | year = 2001 | title = Neural correlates of simple and complex mental calculation | journal = NeuroImage | publisher = Elsevier Science 2001 | volume = 13 | issue = 2 | pages = 314–327 | doi = 10.1006/nimg.2000.0697 | pmid = 11162272}}</ref> Showing that these subsets of arithmetic skills are supported by different brain mechanisms offers the opportunity for a deeper understanding of the learning processes required to acquire arithmetic proficiency.
Neuroimaging studies of mathematical learning disabilities are still rare but dyscalculia is an area of increasing interest for neuroscience researchers. Since different neural mechanisms contribute to different elements of mathematical performance, it may be that children with dyscalculia show variable patterns of abnormality at the brain level. For example, many children with dyscalculia also have dyslexia, and those that do may show different activation of the verbal networks that support maths, while those who have dyscalculia only, may show impairments of the parietal number sense system. Indeed, the few studies carried out on children with dyscalculia only point to a brain level impairment of the number sense system.<ref name = Price2007 /><ref name = Kucian2006>{{cite journal | last1 = Kucian | first1 = K | last2 = Loenneker | first2 = T | last3 = Dietrich | first3 = T | last4 = Dosch | first4 = M | last5 = Martin | first5 = E | last6 = von Aster | first6 = M | year = 2006 | title = Impaired neural networks for approximate calculation in dyscalculic children: a functional MRI study | url = http://www.behavioralandbrainfunctions.com/content/2/1/31 | journal = Behavioral and Brain Functions | publisher = BioMed Central Ltd. | volume = 2 | page = 31 | doi = 10.1186/1744-9081-2-31 | pmc = 1574332 | pmid = 16953876 | issue=1}}</ref>
Such evidence is beginning to contribute to a theoretical debate between researchers who believe that dyscalculia is caused by a brain level deficit of the number sense and those who believe that the disorder stems from a problem in using numerical symbols to access the number sense information. With the continued development of theoretical models of dyscalculia that generate explicit testable hypotheses, progress should be rapid in developing research which investigates the link between mathematical learning disorders and their neural correlates.<ref name = Willingham2009 />
===Social and emotional cognition=== {{Main|Social neuroscience}}
In the last 10 years, there has been an explosion of interest in the role of emotional abilities and characteristics in contributing to success in all aspects of life. The concept of [[Emotional Intelligence]] (EI)<ref>Salovey, P. and D.J. Sluyter, Emotional development and emotional intelligence: Educational implications. 1997: Basic Books.</ref> has gained wide recognition and is featured in the Foresight report on Mental Capital and Wellbeing. Some have made influential claims that EI is more important than conventional cognitive intelligence, and that it can more easily be enhanced.<ref>Goleman, D., Emotional intelligence. New York, 1995.</ref> Systematic research has yet to provide much support for these claims, although EI has been found to be associated with academic success<ref name = Goswami2006 /><ref>Petrides, K.V., N. Frederickson, and A. Furnham, The role of trait emotional intelligence in academic performance and deviant behavior at school.
