{{Multiple issues| {{no footnotes|date=April 2017}} {{like resume|date=April 2017}} }}
{{Infobox person | name = Robby Cantarutti | image = Robby Cantarutti - Italian Architect and Designer.jpg | alt=Robby Cantarutti - Italian Architect and Designer | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1966|6|17|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Wuppertal]], [[Germany]] | occupation = Architect, Designer | years_active = 1995–present | spouse = Francesca Petricich | children = Gaia, Elena | website = {{url|www.archazione.com}} }} '''Robby Cantarutti''' (born 17 June 1966) is an Italian [[architect]] and [[industrial designer]] from [[Venice]] and the best known practitioner of Italian [[Rationalism]]. Cantarutti's works reflect an individualized and distinctive style. Most are located in [[Friuli Venezia Giulia]], including his Cabin at the River, where he lives with his family.[[File:Awarded Cabin at the River - architects Robby Cantarutti Francesca Petricic.jpg|thumb|[[c:File:Awarded Cabin at the River - architects Robby Cantarutti Francesca Petricic.jpg|Awarded Cabin at the River - architects Robby Cantarutti Francesca Petricich]]|left]][[File:Chairs-table by Robby Cantarutti.jpg|thumb|chairs and table by Robby Cantarutti|left]]Cantarutti's work was influenced by his passions in life: [[architecture]] and nature. Cantarutti considered every detail of his creations and integrated into his [[architecture]] such crafts as wood, clear glass and raw [[ironwork]]. He also introduced new techniques in the treatment of materials, such as natural aging by [[atmospheric]] conditions.
==Style== Under the influence of [[Bauhaus]] and [[Le Corbusier]], Cantarutti transcended mainstream [[Rationalism]], culminating in an organic style inspired by natural materials. Cantarutti's work enjoys global popularity and continuing admiration and study by [[architects]]. His masterpiece, the Cabin at the River was also substance of the film “[https://pro-labs.imdb.com/title/tt6676214?d=inprod Cabin at the River]” directed by [https://pro-labs.imdb.com/name/nm0890298/?ref_=sch_int Silvia Zeitlinger] and was awarded with the [http://www.arena-international.com/leafawards/winners-2016/2015-winners/ Green LEAF Award 2015] for Best Single House [[Architecture]] 2015. It is the most-photographed and filmed private [[building]] in [[Italy]]. Leading [[Lifestyle (sociology)|life style]] companies like [[Illy]], [https://www.knoll.com Knoll] use the Cabin as a [[filming location]] for their promotion work.
==Furniture== Cantarutti´s [[Industrial design|Industrial Design]] is distributed by the companies [http://www.vibia.com/en/ Vibia] and [http://www.fastspa.com/uk/azienda.asp Fast] all over the world. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Pedestrian bridge in Rizzi Udine - Architect Robby Cantarutti (Italy).jpg|thumb|Pedestrian bridge in Rizzi Udine - architect Robby Cantarutti (Italy)]] -->
==Architecture work== *1998 - reconstruction [[Premariacco]] [[Udine]] *1999 - several [[single-family homes]] in [[Udine]] *2000 - reconstruction of a [[single-family home]] in Udine *2001 - [[single-family home]] in [[Campoformido]] Udine *2002 - industrial building in [[Campoformido]] Udine *2005 - edificio destinato a clinica casa allogio a [[Cussignacco]] Udine *2005 - winner of the competition for the reconstruction of the Piazza dei Martiri di Cittadella Padova *2006 - bridge Ciclopedonale location [[Rizzi]] Udine [[File:Clinic in Udine -Friuli Venezia Giulia -architect Robby Cantarutti.png|alt=Clinic in Udine -Friuli Venezia Giulia -architect Robby Cantarutti|thumb|Clinic in Udine - Friuli Venezia Giulia - architect Robby Cantarutti]]
==Design work== *Chair Lachaise for ETA spa 1995 *Poltroncina Spock for ETA spa 1995 *Sedia Bauhaus Collection for Natison Chair 1996 *Chair Pocket per Arrmet 1997 *Chair Orbit per Sintesi 2002 *Sgabello Ginger per Sintesi 2002 *Chair Gaia per Airnova 2003 *Libreria funcube per natison sedia 2003 *Chair Jo per Arrmet 2004 *Poltrona Maxo per Arrmet 2004 *Chair Exyte per jds 2006 *Chair Brillant per Figurae 2006 *Sgabello Estro per Alea Office 2006 *Kanapee Alma Alea Office 2006 *Liberia Code for Sintesi 2007 *Chair Forest for fast spa 2010 *Chair Elena per tramo 2010 *Lampada Samurai per vibia 2011 *Lampada Infinity per Vibia 2011 *Chair Niwa per fast spa 2015 *[[Pole marquee|marquee]] da sole Domea per bat 2016 *[[Pole marquee|marquee]] Qubica per ke 2016 *Remote control for [[Pole marquee|marquee]] 2016
==Awards Design== *1996 - award top ten (promosedia ) for chair chaise *1997 - award top ten (promosedia ) for “Bauhaus” collection *2002 - award top ten (promosedia ) for chair “ orbit “ *2003 - award catas per la sedia innovativa e affidabile con lo sgabello “ginger” *2007 - gold medal at the competition [http://neocon.com Neocon Chicago] con la sedia “elena” *2007 - segnalazione al premio delta Spagna con la sedia “elena” *2011 - award red dot germania con sedia “forest” *2011 - award Asiad Usa with the chair “forest” *2017 - award trophees Francia with marquee “qubica” *2017 - [https://productdesignaward.eu/winners/winner.php?id=8477 European Product Design Award] *2017 - [https://competition.adesignaward.com/design.php?ID=56901 A´Design Award&Competition ] for Filoferru Outdoor Chair in Furniture, Homeware Design Category, 2016 - 2017 [[File:MantaChair Cantarutti.jpg|alt= MantaChair designed by Robby Cantarutti|thumb|MantaChair designed by Robby Cantarutti]]
==References== *[https://divisare.com/authors/10018811-robby-cantarutti article about Cantarutti in] [[Divisare|DIVISARE]] *[https://www.architonic.com/en/microsite/robby-cantarutti/8104482 Cantarutti in ARCHITONIC] *[https://www.professionearchitetto.it/news/notizie/21788/Leaf-Awards-2015-tra-i-vincitori-Robby-Cantarutti-3TI-Progetti-e-LAN magazine Professione Architetto about LEAF award] *[http://www.areadeclic.com/designers/robby-cantarutti area Declic] *[https://www.stylepark.com/en/designer/robby-cantarutti STYLESPARK] *[http://www.marieclaire.it/Casa/Design/Designer/Robby-Cantarutti-designers Marie Claire Maison] *[http://www.italchair.it/en/designer/robby-cantarutti ITALCHAIR] *[[Corriere della Sera]] [http://living.corriere.it/case/minimal/casa-cantarutti-cucina-50212589503/ "Living in the Kitchen"] *[http://messaggeroveneto.gelocal.it/udine/cronaca/2015/10/24/news/ecco-la-capanna-sul-fiume-che-conquista-l-europa-1.12321879 Messaggero Veneto] *[https://www.professionearchitetto.it/news/notizie/21788/Leaf-Awards-2015-tra-i-vincitori-Robby-Cantarutti-3TI-Progetti-e-LAN Professione Architetto]
==External links== *[https://www.archazione.com website] *[https://paddle8.com/work/robby-cantarutti/12584-manta-chair Paddle8 Manta chair] *[http://bucharest.iegis.eu/speaker/2016-team-robby-cantarutti-en/ Bucharest International Architecture Forum] *[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm8863803/?ref_=fn_al_nm_7 Robby Cantarutti] [[IMDb]]

'''Roger Säljö''' (born 2 April 1948) is a [[Swedish people|Swedish]] [[educational psychology|educational psychologist]] whose research presents a socio-cultural perspective on human [[learning]] and [[Developmental psychology|development]]. Säljö is a professor of education and educational psychology at [[Göteborg University]] and was president of the [[European Association for Research on Learning and Instruction]] (EARLI) between 2005 and 2007. Roger Säljö is the director of a national centre of excellence in research.
==See also==
*[[Ference Marton]]
==External links== * [http://www.ipkl.gu.se/english/contact/staff/roger.saljo/publications Publications] * [http://www.earli.org/about_earli/executive_committee European Association for Research on Learning and Instruction]
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Saljo, Roger}} [[Category:Educational psychologists]] [[Category:University of Gothenburg faculty]] [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:Living people]]
{{Sweden-bio-stub}}

[[File:Chart for roundtable discussion.jpg|thumbnail|Round table with Barack Obama in Minneapolis]]
'''Round table''' is a form of academic discussion. Participants agree on a specific topic to discuss and debate. Each person is given equal right to participate, as illustrated by the idea of a circular layout referred to in the term [[round table]].
Round-table discussions, together with houses of hospitality and agronomic universities, is one of the key elements of the [[Catholic Worker Movement]], as formulated by [[Peter Maurin]], one of the co-founders of the movement.<ref>http://www.catholicworker.org/roundtable/index.cfm</ref>
Round table discussions are also a common feature of political talk shows. Talk shows such as ''[[Washington Week]]'' and ''[[Meet the Press]]'' have roundtables of reporters or pundits. Most of these are done around a table in a studio, but occasionally they report in split-screen from remote locations. Some sports shows, such as [[ESPN]]'s ''[[Around the Horn]]'', employ the round table format. The round table method is still highly used to this day.
==See also== *[[Academic conference]] *[[Round Table (disambiguation)]]
== References == {{reflist}}

{{orphan|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox organization |name = The Ronesans Education Foundation |fgcolor = |image = Rönesans_Education_Foundation_logo.png |image_border = |size = |alt = |caption = |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |abbreviation = REV |motto = |formation = |type = [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]] |status = |purpose = |headquarters = [[Istanbul]], Turkey |location = |coords = |region_served = |membership = |language = |leader_title = |leader_name = Refia Jale Ilıcak |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = {{URL| http://www.rev.com.tr/ }} }} The Ronesans Education Foundation was established in 2009 by the [[Rönesans Holding]] Honorary President Bekir Ilıcak. The Foundation keeps on maintaining its activities through the donations of Ilıcak family. The Rönesans Education Foundation Board of Directors President is Refia Jale Ilıcak. The Foundation is providing non-refundable grant scholarship for undergraduate and postgraduate students and implementing various projects at homeland and abroad, in fields of health, culture, science and sports, education being at first place. <ref>http://www.egitimajansi.com/haber/ronesanstan-1232-ogrenciye-daha-egitim-bursu-haberi-34538h.html</ref><ref>http://emlakkulisi.com/ronesans-egitim-vakfi-cocuklari-sevindirmeye-devam-ediyor/220471</ref>

revision.text:
[[File:Leeuwin Barracks.jpg|alt=Leeuwin Barracks, Australia|thumb|[[HMAS Leeuwin (naval base)|Leeuwin Barracks]], [[Australia]], site of widespread sexual abuse of child navy recruits between 1967 and 1971.{{Cite web|url=https://www.childabuseroyalcommission.gov.au/sites/default/files/case_study_40_-_findings_report_-_australian_defence_force.pdf|title=Report of case study no. 40: The response of the Australian Defence Force to allegations of child sexual abuse|last=Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse|date=2017|website=|access-date=2018-03-09}}]] '''Sexual harassment in the military''' is unwanted [[Human sexual activity|sexual behaviour]], which is defined as threatening, offensive, or otherwise upsetting to others in a [[military]] setting. The behaviour is more common in the military than in [[civilian]] life. Women are substantially more likely than men to experience [[sexual harassment]] in the armed forces. Other groups at higher risk include child cadets/recruits and military [[Detention (imprisonment)|detainees]]. == Definitions == [[Sexual harassment]] is unwanted [[Human sexual activity|sexual behaviour]] which is threatening or otherwise upsetting to others. Some example definitions in use by state armed forces are: * [[Australian Defence Force|Australian Defence Forces]]: Unwanted sexual advances or sexual requests towards to another person{{Cite web|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/Health/HealthPortal/UnacceptableBehaviour.asp|title=Unacceptable Behaviour in the Workplace|last=Australia, Department of Defence|date=2013-03-15|website=www.defence.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2018-03-08}} * [[British Army|British Army]]: Unwanted sexually based conduct or other conduct affecting the dignity of women and men at work.{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/446224/ADR005000-Sexual_Harassment_Report.pdf|title=Sexual harassment report 2015|last=British army|date=2015|website=gov.uk|access-date=2018-03-08}} * [[Canadian Armed Forces|Canadian Armed Forces]]: Improper conduct directed at and offensive to others, which the perpetrator ought reasonably know would be so.{{Cite web|url=http://www.forces.gc.ca/assets/FORCES_Internet/docs/en/caf-community-support-services-harassment/era-final-report-(april-20-2015)-eng.pdf|title=External Review into Sexual Misconduct and Sexual Harassment in the Canadian Armed Forces|last=Deschamps|first=Marie|date=2015|website=forces.gc.ca|access-date=2018-03-08}} * [[United States Armed Forces|United States Armed Forces]]: Unwanted sexual advances and other behaviour of a sexual nature.{{Cite web|url=http://www.quantico.marines.mil/Portals/147/Docs/Resources/RCO/RCO_Attachment%201%20to%20USMC%20RFQ%20M00264-12-T-0119.pdf|title=Sexual Assault vs. Sexual Harassment|last=US, Department of Defense|date=|website=marines.mil|access-date=2018-03-08}} == Behaviour == {{Main|Sexual harassment}} Sexual harassment in the military includes a broad spectrum of behaviour. Undirected behaviours that affect the working environment, such as sexist jokes and the prominent display of [[Pornography|pornographic material]], may constitute sexual harassment, as do directed behaviours targeted at one or more individuals, such as unwanted sexual advances and [[sexual assault]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.mod.uk/NR/rdonlyres/538E55EE-9CA4-4177-9A0B-6853A431B283/0/20060522SRReport.pdf|title=Quantitative & qualitative research into sexual harassment in the armed forces|last=Rutherford|first=Sarah|last2=Schneider|first2=Robin|date=2006|website=|archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20121018171845/http://www.mod.uk/NR/rdonlyres/538E55EE-9CA4-4177-9A0B-6853A431B283/0/20060522SRReport.pdf|archive-date=2012-10-18|dead-url=bot: unknown|access-date=2018-03-08|last3=Walmsley|first3=Alexis|df=}} Research in Canada has found that a culture of undirected sexual harassment increases the risk of directed sexual harassment and assault. === Case examples === In the [[British Army|British army]], a woman told the following story to researchers in 2006:
‘A friend was out on an [[Military exercise|exercise]] when a group of men ducked her head in a bucket of water and each time she came up for breath she had to repeat “I am useless and I am a female”. She told the story and said it was a joke but I could see she was upset.’
In the [[Canadian Armed Forces|Canadian armed forces]], demeaning attitudes to women are pervasive, according to the ''Deschamps Review'' of 2015:
'Interviewees reported regularly being told of orders to “stop being pussies” and to “leave your purses at home” [...] The use of the word “cunt”, for example, is commonplace, and rape jokes are tolerated. [...] A commonly held attitude is that, rather than be a soldier, a sailor or an aviator, a woman will be labeled an “ice princess”, a “bitch”, or a “slut”. Another saying is that women enter the CAF “to find a man, to leave a man, or to become a man”.'
A woman in the [[French Army|French army]], [[pseudonym]]ised by the ''[[The Independent|Independent]]'' newspaper as Captain Carole, was [[rape]]d by her commanding officer:
'It was months before I could pronounce the word "rape"... I blamed myself. I said: "We are trained in hand to hand combat. Why didn’t I stop him?" But when that happens you are terrorised.'{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/france-battles-sexual-abuse-in-the-military-9271383.html|title=France battles sexual abuse in the military|last=Lichfield|first=John|date=2014-04-20|work=Independent|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en-GB}}
== Prevalence and risk factors == Studies of sexual harassment have found that it is markedly more common in [[military]] than [[civilian]] settings.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/828143812|title=Military psychologists' desk reference|last=Anderson|first=E H|last2=Suris|first2=A|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2013|isbn=978-0-19-992826-2|editor-last=Moore|editor-first=Brett A|location=Oxford|pages=264–269|chapter=Military sexual trauma|oclc=828143812|editor-last2=Barnett|editor-first2=Jeffrey E}} Several reasons for this have been suggested. A Canadian study found that key risk factors associated with military settings are the typically young age of personnel, the isolated locations of bases, the minority status of women, and the disproportionate number of men in senior positions.{{Cite web|url=https://cimvhr.ca/conference/mh-symposium/documents/presentations/5-Watkins.pdf|title=Sexual Assault in the Canadian Armed Forces: Prevalence, Circumstances, Correlates, and Mental Health Associations|last=Watkins|first=Kimberley|last2=Bennett|first2=Rachel|date=|website=|access-date=2018-03-08|last3=Richer|first3=Isabelle|last4=Zamorski|first4=Mark}} Other Canadian research has found that an emphasis in military organisations on [[conformity]], [[Obedience (human behavior)|obedience]], and [[Hierarchy|hierarchical power relations]], combine to increase the risk, particularly to personnel of low rank, who are less able than others to resist inappropriate expectations made of them. The [[Masculinity|traditionally masculine]] values and behaviours that are rewarded and reinforced in military settings are also thought to play a role.{{Cite journal|last=Gallagher|first=Kathryn E.|last2=Parrott|first2=Dominic J.|date=May 2011|title=What accounts for men's hostile attitudes toward women? The influence of hegemonic male role norms and masculine gender role stress| journal=Violence Against Women|volume=17|issue=5|pages=568–583|doi=10.1177/1077801211407296 | pmc=3143459|pmid=21531691}}{{Cite journal|last=Parrott|first=Dominic J.|last2=Zeichner|first2=Amos|title=Effects of hypermasculinity oh physical aggression against women.|url=http://doi.apa.org/getdoi.cfm?doi=10.1037/1524-9220.4.1.70|journal=Psychology of Men & Masculinity|language=en|volume=4|issue=1|pages=70–78|doi=10.1037/1524-9220.4.1.70}}{{Cite journal|last=Rosen et al|first=Leora N|date=September 2003|title=The Effects of Peer Group Climate on Intimate Partner Violence among Married Male U.S. Army Soldiers|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/1077801203255504|journal=Violence Against Women|volume=9|issue=9|pages=1045–1071|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Baugher|first=Amy R.|last2=Gazmararian|first2=Julie A.|title=Masculine gender role stress and violence: A literature review and future directions|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1359178915000403|journal=Aggression and Violent Behavior|volume=24|pages=107–112|doi=10.1016/j.avb.2015.04.002}} Canadian research has also found that the risk of sexual misconduct increases during deployment on [[military operation]]s. == Principal targets == === Female personnel === While some male personnel are sexually harassed, women are substantially more likely to be affected. Women who are younger and joined the military at a younger age face a greater risk, according to American, British, Canadian, and French research.{{Cite web|url=https://www.apha.org/policies-and-advocacy/public-health-policy-statements/policy-database/2014/07/23/11/19/cessation-of-military-recruiting-in-public-elementary-and-secondary-schools|title=Cessation of Military Recruiting in Public Elementary and Secondary Schools|last=American Public Heatlh Association|date=2013-10-30|website=www.apha.org|access-date=2018-03-08}} === Child cadets === Cadet forces are military youth organisations for younger teenagers based in communities and schools, and are common around the world.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cadets.ca/en/what-cadets-do/army.page|title=Royal Canadian Army Cadets|last=Government of Canada|date=|website=|language=en|access-date=2018-03-09}}{{Cite web|url=http://ethosworld.com/library/The-New-Profile-Report-On-Child-Recruitment-in-israel-2004.pdf|title=Child Recruitment in Israel|last=New Profile|date=2004|website=|access-date=2018-03-09}}{{Cite web|url=https://armycadets.com/join-cadets/|title=Join The Army Cadets|last=Army Cadet Force|date=2018|language=en|access-date=2018-03-09}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.usarmyjrotc.com/|title=U.S. Army JROTC|last=US Army|date=2018|website=www.usarmyjrotc.com|access-date=2018-03-09}} There is some evidence from the UK, where hundreds of complaints of the sexual abuse of cadets have been recorded since 2012, and from Canada, where one in ten complaints of sexual assault in the military are from cadets, that these institutions are susceptible to a culture of sexual harassment.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-40457123|title=Sex abuse against cadets 'covered up'|last=Razzall|first=Katie|date=2017-07-04|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-03-09|last2=MacSorley|first2=Jane|language=en-GB}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2014/dec/28/ministry-of-defence-pays-out-2m-settle-cadets-sexual-abuse-claims|title=Ministry of Defence pays out £2m to settle cadets’ sexual abuse claims|last=Quinn|first=Ben|date=2014-12-28|website=Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-03-09}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/jul/04/mod-admits-over-350-sexual-abuse-complaints-have-been-made-by-cadets|title=MoD admits over 350 sexual abuse complaints have been made by cadets|last=Rawlinson|first=Kevin|date=2017-07-04|website=Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-03-09}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.vice.com/en_ca/article/xdm7kn/canadian-military-cadet-program-has-a-sexual-assault-problem-documents-show-674|title=Documents Show the Canadian Army Cadets Program Is Plagued With Sexual Abuse Allegations|date=2014-11-26|work=Vice|access-date=2018-03-10|language=en-ca}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.macleans.ca/news/canada/our-militarys-disgrace/|title=Our military's disgrace|last=Mercier|first=Noémi|date=2014-05-16|work=Macleans.ca|access-date=2018-03-10|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140516222347/http://www.macleans.ca/news/canada/our-militarys-disgrace/|archive-date=2014-05-16|dead-url=yes|last2=Castonguay|first2=Alec|language=en-US}} === Detainees === Individuals detained by the military are particularly vulnerable to sexual harassment. During the [[Iraq War]], for example, personnel of the [[United States Army|US army]] and [[Central Intelligence Agency|US Central Intelligence Agency]] committed a number of [[human rights violations]] against detainees in the [[Abu Ghraib prison]],{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/news/abu_ghraib/2006/03/14/chapter_5/index.html|title=Other government agencies|last=Greenwald|first=Glenn|publisher=Salon.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080212035108/http://www.salon.com/news/abu_ghraib/2006/03/14/chapter_5/index.html|archivedate=February 12, 2008|deadurl=yes|accessdate=April 3, 2012|df=mdy}} including [[rape]], [[sodomy]], and other forms of sexual abuse.{{cite news|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2004/05/17/040517fa_fact2?currentPage=all|title=Chain of Command|last=Hersh|first=Seymour M.|date=May 17, 2004|work=The New Yorker|accessdate=September 13, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120101055751/http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2004/05/17/040517fa_fact2?currentPage=all|archivedate=January 1, 2012|deadurl=no|quote=NBC News later quoted U.S. military officials as saying that the unreleased photographs showed American soldiers "severely beating an Iraqi prisoner nearly to death, having sex with a female Iraqi prisoner, and 'acting inappropriately with a dead body.' The officials said there also was a videotape, apparently shot by U.S. personnel, showing Iraqi guards raping young boys."|df=mdy-all}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2009/05/30/taguba/|title=Taguba denies he's seen abuse photos suppressed by Obama: The general told a U.K. paper about images he saw investigating Abu Ghraib – not photos Obama wants kept secret.|last=Benjamin|first=Mark|date=May 30, 2008|work=Salon.com|accessdate=June 6, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090611145722/http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2009/05/30/taguba/|archivedate=June 11, 2009|deadurl=no|quote=The paper quoted Taguba as saying, "These pictures show torture, abuse, rape and every indecency." [...] The actual quote in the Telegraph was accurate, Taguba said – but he was referring to the hundreds of images he reviewed as an investigator of the abuse at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq}}{{cite news|url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2007/06/25/070625fa_fact_hersh?printable=true|title=The general's report: how Antonio Taguba, who investigated the Abu Ghraib scandal, became one of its casualties.|last=Hersh|first=Seymour Myron|date=June 25, 2007|work=The New Yorker|accessdate=June 17, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070912104000/http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2007/06/25/070625fa_fact_hersh?printable=true|archivedate=September 12, 2007|deadurl=no|quote=Taguba said that he saw "a video of a male American soldier in uniform sodomizing a female detainee"|authorlink=Seymour Hersh|df=mdy-all}} Another example is the detention of two Iraqi men on a British warship at the start of the Iraq War, when they were made to strip naked and were then sexually humiliated.{{Cite web|url=https://www.leighday.co.uk/News/News-2017/December-2017/High-Court-finds-MoD-breached-the-Geneva-Conventio|title=High Court finds MoD breached the Geneva Conventions during the Iraq War|last=Leigh Day|date=2017-12-14|website=|access-date=2018-03-14}} == Barriers to redress == Although the risk of sexual misconduct in the armed forces is widely acknowledged, personnel are frequently reluctant to report incidents.{{Cite news|url=https://www.defense.gov/News/Article/Article/1168765/dod-releases-latest-military-sexual-assault-report/|title=DoD Releases Latest Military Sexual Assault Report|last=US, Department of Defence|date=2017-05-01|access-date=2018-03-09|language=en-US}} For example: * An official report of the [[Australian Defence Force]] concluded that women affected by harassment were less likely to make a complaint because they do not expect a serious response.{{Cite web|url=https://www.defenceabusetaskforce.gov.au/Reports/Documents/Dart-final-report-2016.pdf|title=Defence Abuse Response Taskforce: Final report|last=Defence Abuse Response Taskforce|date=2016|website=|access-date=2018-03-08}} * The [[ombudsman]] of the [[Canadian Armed Forces|Canadian armed forces]] confirmed that women fear the consequences if they report a sexual offence against them to their [[command hierarchy|chain of command]]: 'The fear of repercussions is blatant,' he said in 2014. In 2015, the Deschamps Review reported that one of the main reasons why personnel do not lodge a complaint is a fear of the consequences for their career and that there had many complainants had faced reprisals. * Leila Minano, the co-author of a book documenting sexual abuse in the [[French Armed Forces|French armed forces]], commented that complaints from women were systematically discouraged from complaining, and were often moved out of their unit if they did so. * In the UK, an official report on sexual harassment in the [[British Army|British army]] found that almost half of personnel who had an 'upsetting' experience of sexual harassment did not complain for fear of an impact on their career. * In the [[United States Armed Forces|US armed forces]], a study in 2016 found that 58% of women who reported sexual misconduct by peers said that they had met with retaliation as a consequence.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/sexual-assault-reports-u-s-military-reach-record-high-pentagon-n753566|title=Sexual assault reports in U.S. military reach record high, Pentagon says|work=NBC News|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en}} The Department of Defense estimated in 2017 that two in three victims of sexual assault do not report it. Since the number of official complaints represents only a fraction of sexual harassment in the military,{{Cite web|url=http://sapr.mil/public/docs/reports/FY16_Annual/FY16_SAPRO_Annual_Report.pdf|title=Department of Defense Annual Report on Sexual Assault in the Military: Fiscal Year 2016|last=US, Department of Defense|date=2017|website=|access-date=2018-03-09}} armed forces that have committed to reduce prevalence produce periodic estimates of its extent using anonymised surveys. == Mental health effects == Women affected by sexual harassment are more likely than other women to suffer [[Stress (biology)|stress]]-related [[Mental disorder|mental illness]] afterwards. Research in the US found that when [[sexual abuse]] of female military personnel is [[Psychological trauma|psychiatrically traumatic]], the odds of suffering from [[Posttraumatic stress disorder|post-traumatic stress disorder]] (PTSD) after deployment on operations increase by a factor of nine. Research in the US has found that personnel affected by sexual harassment are somewhat less likely to develop depression or PTSD if a formal report leads to effective action to address the issue.{{Cite journal|last=Bell|first=Margret E.|last2=Street|first2=Amy E.|last3=Stafford|first3=Jane|date=2014|title=Victims' psychosocial well-being after reporting sexual harassment in the military|journal=Journal of trauma & dissociation: the official journal of the International Society for the Study of Dissociation (ISSD)|volume=15|issue=2|pages=133–152|doi=10.1080/15299732.2014.867563|issn=1529-9740|pmid=24410254}} == Prevention == [[File:US Army SHARP Sexual Harassment and Sexual Assault Prevention Poster.jpg|link=[[:File:US Army SHARP Sexual Harassment and Sexual Assault Prevention Poster]].jpg|thumb| Poster created by the [[U.S. Army]]'s [[Sexual Harassment/Assault Response & Prevention]] (SHARP) ]] The military leadership in some countries has begun to acknowledge a culture of sexual misconduct in the armed forces. For example: * The British armed forces co-commissioned their first formal study of the problem in 2006, and in 2016 the head of the [[British Army|British army]] noted the ‘overly sexualised’ soldier culture and committed to reducing the extent of sexual misconduct.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/06/14/army-has-overly-sexualised-heavy-drinking-culture-head-of-armed/|title=Army has 'overly-sexualised' heavy drinking culture, Chief of General Staff admits|last=Farmer|first=Ben|date=2016-06-14|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-03-08|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}} * In 2016, after a major study uncovered widespread sexual harassment and assault in the Canadian armed forces, [[Jonathan Vance|General Jonathan Vance]], Chief of the Defence Staff, acknowledged: 'Harmful sexual behaviour is a real problem in our institution.'{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/sexual-misconduct-military-survey-1.3868377|title=960 soldiers reported being sexually assaulted in the past year|last=Harris|first=Kathleen|date=2016-11-28|work=CBC News|access-date=2018-03-14|language=en}} * The US established the Sexual Assault Prevention and Response Office in 2005, which reports annually.{{Cite web|url=http://sapr.mil/index.php/about/mission-and-history|title=Mission & History|last=US, Department of Defense|date=2018|website=|language=en-us|access-date=2018-03-09}} == Sexual harassment in the military, by country == === Australia === Widespread reports of sexual harassment in the [[Australian Defence Force|Australian armed forces]] led to the establishment of the [[Defence Abuse Response Taskforce]] to investigate complaints from women between 1991 and 2011. It received 2,439 complaints, of which it deemed 1,751 to be plausible. A [[Royal Commission]] into institutional [[child sexual abuse]] was established in 2012, which investigated widespread allegations of historical abuse in the navy. The Commission took evidence from 8,000 individuals{{Cite news|url=https://www.childabuseroyalcommission.gov.au/private-sessions|title=Private sessions|last=Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse|date=2017-05-30|access-date=2018-03-09|language=en}} and reported in 2017 that many recruits of both sexes and from the age of 15 had been repeatedly sexually abused by older recruits between 1967 and 1971, including by anal [[gang rape]], and in some cases young recruits had been forced to rape each other. The practice was ‘tolerated’ by senior staff, according to the Commission.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2017/aug/22/navy-staff-tolerated-widespread-child-sexual-abuse-of-recruits-royal-commission-says|title=Navy staff tolerated widespread child sexual abuse of recruits, royal commission says|last=Australian Associated Press|date=2017-08-22|website=Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-03-08}}{{Further|Defence Abuse Response Taskforce|Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse}} === Canada === {{Main|Sexual assault in the Canadian Forces}}According to official statistics gathered by [[Maclean's|''Maclean's'' magazine]], the Canadian military police received an average of 178 complaints of sexual assault between 2000 and 2014, representing an estimated 10% of all cases. In 2014, the [[ombudsman]] of the Canadian armed forces described sexual harassment in the institution as 'a huge problem'. In 2015, after widespread allegations of sexual misconduct in the military, a major official report, the ''External Review into Sexual Misconduct and Sexual Harassment in the Canadian Armed Forces'' (the ''Deschamps Review''), was published. It found that sexual harassment was commonplace and embedded in military culture, and that pervasive degrading attitudes to women and LGBTQ personnel were jeopardising their safety. The ''Deschamps Review'' also criticised the armed forces for a culture of dismissiveness. One male interview told the Review, for example: "Girls that come to the Army know what to expect." It stated that senior [[Non-commissioned officer|NCOs]] are frequently seen as tolerating sexual harassment and discouraging the individuals affected from making a complaint. The following year, in 2016, a major study of 43,000 [[Canadian Armed Forces|Canadian armed forces]] personnel reported that 27% of female personnel reported at least one incident of sexual assault since they joined the military, and 5% of female regular armed forces personnel reported the same in the previous 12 months (equivalent to approximately 960 women per year). === France === The extent of sexual harassment in the [[French Armed Forces|French armed forces]] first came to light in 2014 when 35 cases of sexual harassment and assault were detailed in ''La Guerre Invisible'', a book by Leila Minano and Julia Pascual.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/871236655|title=La guerre invisible: révélations sur les violences sexuelles dans l'armée française|last=Leila|first=Miñano|last2=Pascual|first2=Julia|publisher=Les Arènes|others=|year=2014|isbn=2352043026|location=Paris|pages=|language=fr|oclc=871236655}} According to the ''[[The Independent|Independent]]'' newspaper, the armed forces had not been required to report incidents or to keep statistics, and an official report acknowledged that awareness of the problem had been institutionally suppressed. === United Kingdom === Following concerns expressed in 2004 by the UK Equal Opportunities Commission (now the [[Equality and Human Rights Commission]]) about persistent sexual harassment in the British armed forces, a number of anonymised, official surveys have been undertaken. The first, in 2006, found that a male-dominated culture sexualised women and diminished their military competence. Among the comments made to researchers by male personnel about their female counterparts were: ‘Ok there are a few exceptions but on the whole they [women] shouldn’t be here.’; 'They're all [[lesbian]]s or [[slut]]s.'; and 'They are emotionally unstable.' The report found that 15% of women had had a 'particularly upsetting' experience of sexual harassment in the previous 12 months; the proportion rose to 20% in the youngest age group. A similar survey in 2009 found the 8% of women in the army had had a ‘particularly upsetting’ experience in the previous 12 months, and the most recent survey, in 2015, found that 13% of women reported the same. In 2017, a [[Panorama (TV series)|BBC ''Panorama'']] documentary found multiple cases of the sexual abuse of cadets from age 11 during the 1980s, and reported that the victims and their parents were discouraged from making a formal complaint or contacting the police. The [[Ministry of Defence]] paid £2 million in 2012 and 2013 to settle allegations of the child sexual abuse of military cadets, and between 2012 and 2017 recorded a further 363 allegations, of which 282 were referred to the police. === United States === {{Main|Military sexual trauma|Sexual assault in the United States military}}In 2017, the Department of Defense reported that an estimated 14,900 military personnel were sexually assaulted in 2016, of whom 6,172 made an official complaint. According to an article published in ''[[Medscape]]'', up to 80% of women in the armed forces have been sexually harassed, and 25% have experienced a sexual assault.{{Cite web|url=https://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/781380_3|title=Mission Critical: Getting Vets With PTSD Back to Work|last=Meade|first=Barbara J|last2=Glenn|first2=Margaret K|date=2013-03-29|website=www.medscape.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160315173801/http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/781380_3|archive-date=2016-03-15|dead-url=yes|access-date=2018-03-08}} == See also == * [[Sexual harassment]] and [[Wartime sexual violence]] * [[Military personnel]], [[Women in the military]], [[Children in the military]], and [[Military recruitment]] * [[Sexual assault in the United States military]], [[Military sexual trauma (United States armed forces)]] and [[Abu Ghraib torture and prisoner abuse]] * [[Sexual assault in the Canadian Forces]] == References == == External links == === Research === * British army: [http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20121018171845/http://www.mod.uk/NR/rdonlyres/538E55EE-9CA4-4177-9A0B-6853A431B283/0/20060522SRReport.pdf ''Rutherford Report'', 2006], [https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/446224/ADR005000-Sexual_Harassment_Report.pdf ''Sexual Harassment Report'', 2015], [http://vfpuk.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/The-First-Ambush-Effects-of-army-training-and-employment-WEB.pdf ''The First Ambush? Effects of military training and employment, 2017''] * Canadian armed forces: [http://www.forces.gc.ca/assets/FORCES_Internet/docs/en/caf-community-support-services-harassment/era-final-report-(april-20-2015)-eng.pdf ''Dechamps Review, 2016''] * French armed forces: [https://books.google.co.uk/books/about/La_Guerre_invisible.html?id=x99ZBAAAQBAJ&redir_esc=y ''La Guerre Invisible, 2014''] * US armed forces: [http://sapr.mil/ Department of Defense Sexual Assault Prevention and Response Office] === Testimony === * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6GO3xq-64vo Rachel Thompson (British army), 2017] [video] [[Category:Air Cadet Organisation]] [[Category:Air Training Corps]] [[Category:Australian Defence Force]] [[Category:British Armed Forces]] [[Category:Canadian Armed Forces]] [[Category:Canadian Cadet organizations]] [[Category:Child soldiers]] [[Category:Crime]] [[Category:Department of National Defence (Canada)]] [[Category:Human behavior]] [[Category:Military education and training in Canada]] [[Category:Military education and training]] [[Category:Military life]] [[Category:Military of Australia]] [[Category:Military of Canada]] [[Category:Military of France]] [[Category:Military of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Military personnel]] [[Category:Military]] [[Category:Physiology]] [[Category:Sexuality]] [[Category:Uniformed services of Canada]] [[Category:Violence]] [[Category:Women]]

page.title: St. Clement of Ohrid University of Bitola

revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=March 2016}} {{Expand Macedonian|date=December 2008|Универзитет „Св. Климент Охридски“}} {{Infobox University | name=University "St. Kliment Ohridski" - Bitola | native_name=Универзитет „Св. Климент Охридски“ Битола | image= Bitola.uni.jpg | image_size= 150px | latin_name= | established=1979 | type=[[Public university|Public]] | rector=[[Sasho Korunovski]] | students=15,000+ | city=[[Bitola]] | country=[[Republic of Macedonia]] | campus= | affiliations = | website=[http://www.uklo.edu.mk/ www.uklo.edu.mk] |academic_staff=374|administrative_staff=193}} The '''St. Clement of Ohrid University of Bitola''' ({{lang-mk|Универзитет „Св. Климент Охридски“ - Битола|translit=Univerzitet "Sv. Kliment Ohridski"}}) is the second Macedonian state university located mainly in [[Bitola]], with faculties in [[Prilep]], [[Ohrid]], [[Veles (city)|Veles]], [[Kichevo]] and [[Skopje]]. It was founded on 25 April 1979, but the name of [[Clement of Ohrid|St. Clement of Ohrid]] was not given until late 1994. The number of enrolled students exceeds 15,000.
The act of the formal establishment of the university of Bitola was on the 25th April 1979. On 8 December 1994 when the University of Bitola started to celebrate the day of St Clement in honor of theirpatron. The founding assembly was held on 25 April 1979 in Bitola. A Self-Managing Agreement for joining into the University of Bitola was signed by six higher education institutions and two research institutes, namely: * Faculty of Economics – Prilep * Faculty of Law – Bitola * Faculty of Technical Sciences – Bitola * Faculty of Tourism and Catering – Ohrid * Higher School of Agriculture - Bitola * Academy of Pedagogy- Bitola * Tobacco Institute – Prilep * Institute of Hydro-biology- Ohrid
The following institutions have since joined the university: * Institute for Old Slav Culture – Prilep (1985) * National and University Library "St.Kliment Ohridski" – Biota (1980) * Student Center "Koch Racin" – Bitola (1981) * Higher Medical School – Bitola (1988) * Police Academy – Skopje (2004)
The international character of UKLO is confirmed by the participation in international programs and associations among which the most significant is the membership in EUA and BUA. St. Clement of Ohrid University is also a holder of the [[Erasmus+]] Charter.
== Study fields ==
'''''Natural Sciences''''' * Computer & information sciences
'''''Engineering & Technology''''' * Transport engineering * Electrical, electronic and information engineering * Communication engineering and systems * Applied engineering (environmental protection) * Mechanical Engineering * Mechatronics * Graphic Engineering
'''''Medical & Health Sciences''''' * Nursing * Nutrition (gastronomy) * Dietetics * Health care (midwifery, physiotherapy, radiology, medical laboratory) * Forensic science
'''''Agricultural Sciences''''' * Agricultural biotechnology and food biotechnology * Animal products processing * Agronomy, plant breeding and plant protection * Veterinary science
'''''Social Sciences''''' * Economics and Business (finances, management, banking, accounting, auditing, marketing, insurance) * Educational sciences * Law * Tourism and hospitality * Security * Political sciences * Organization science and management
'''''Humanities''''' * Languages * Literature
==Members<ref>http://www.uklo.edu.mk/tabs/view/15f4151621d44cf09b12938ebebfdd41</ref>== 12 higher education institutions (10 faculties, 1 higher school, 1 scientific institute)
4 accompanying units: * Faculty of Economics – Prilep * Faculty of Technical Sciences – Bitola * Faculty of Biotechnical Sciences * Faculty of Education – Bitola * Faculty of Veterinary Medicine – Bitola * Faculty of Information and Communication Technologies – Bitola * Faculty of Tourism and Hospitality – Ohrid * Faculty of Security – Skopje * Faculty of Law – Kichevo * [http://www.ttfv.uklo.edu.mk/index.php/en/ Faculty of Technology and Technical Sciences – Veles] * Higher Medical School – Bitola * Faculty of Information and Communication Technologies – Bitola * Tobacco institute – Prilep
''Accompanying units'' * Hydro-biological institute – Ohrid * Institute for Ancient Slav literature * National Institution University Library "St.Kliment Ohridski" * Students’ residence "Kocho Racin" – Bitola
== International research journal – Horizons == ''Horizons'' is an international research journal of St. Clement of Ohrid University published in two series depending on the research areas: Series A in the area of social sciences and humanities, and Series B in the area of natural sciences and mathematics, engineering and technology, biotechnology, medicine and health sciences. The journal is EBSCO classified.
==See also== * [[Balkan Universities Network]] * [[List of universities in the Republic of Macedonia]] * [[List of colleges and universities]] * [[Bitola]]

page.title: Swedish Institute for Language and Folklore

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category History organisations based in Sweden to [[:Category:History organizations based in Sweden]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 October 25]].
revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=June 2015}} [[File:Logo språkrådet.png|thumb]] The '''Institute for Language and Folklore''', ({{lang-sv|Institutet för språk och folkminnen}}, but commonly referred to by the [[acronym]] '''SOFI'''), is a [[Government agencies in Sweden|Swedish government agency]] with the purpose of studying and collecting materials concerning dialects, folklore and [[onomastics]].
In June 2006 the Swedish government decided to centralize the Swedish language preservation institutes, starting on the July 1, 2006. The former name, Swedish Institute for Dialectology, Onomastics and Folklore Research ({{lang-sv|Språk- och folkminnesinstituet}}) was changed to the current name.
The institute consists of several, originally independent, units, located in different Swedish university towns. The central unit of the institute is located in [[Uppsala]], with other departments located to [[Lund]], [[Gothenburg]], [[Umeå]] and [[Stockholm]].
The institute is, among other things, responsible for the ongoing publication of ''Sveriges ortnamn'' (a dictionary of all Swedish placenames) and ''Sveriges medeltida personnamn'' (a dictionary of medieval Swedish personal names).
==Units of the Institute== * Administrative Unit (Uppsala) * Department of Dialectology, Uppsala (Dialektavdelningen, DA) * Folklore Department, Uppsala (Folkminnesavdelningen, FA) * Phonogram Unit, Uppsala (Fonogramenheten) * Department of Onomastics, Uppsala (Namnavdelning, NA). * Archive for Dialects, Placenames and Folklore in Gothenburg (Dialekt-, ortnamns- och folkminnesarkivet i Göteborg, DAG) * Archive for Dialects and Placenames in Lund (Dialekt- och ortnamnsarkivet i Lund, DAL) * [[Swedish Language Council]] (Språkrådet) * [[Institute for Dialectology, Onomastics and Folklore Research in Umeå|Archive for Dialects, Placenames and Folklore in Umeå]] (Dialekt-, ortnamns- och folkminnesarkivet i Umeå, DAUM)
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://www.sprakochfolkminnen.se SOFI], main website * [http://www.sprakochfolkminnen.se/om-oss/kontakt/dialekt--och-ortnamnsarkivet-i-lund.html DAL] * [http://www.sprakochfolkminnen.se/om-oss/kontakt/dialekt--ortnamns--och-folkminnesarkivet-i-goteborg.html DAG] * [http://www.sprakochfolkminnen.se/om-oss/kontakt/dialekt--ortnamns--och-folkminnesarkivet-i-umea.html DAUM]

revision.text:
{{Other uses|Talis (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox company | name = Talis Group Ltd. | logo = [[image:talis.png|x150px]] | type = [[Private company limited by shares|Private]] | key_people = {{Unbulleted list| Dave Errington, [[CEO]] | Justin Leavesley, [[Chief strategy officer|CSO]] | Tom Hawkins, [[CFO]] | Chris Clarke, [[Chief technology officer|CTO]] }} | industry = [[Computer software]] | num_employees = <!-- ~25 world-wide (Feb 2014)--> | homepage = {{URL|www.talis.com}} | foundation = {{Start date|1969}} | location = [[Birmingham]], [[England]] | parent = [[SAGE Publications]] }}
'''Talis Group Ltd.''' is a software company based in [[Birmingham]], England that develops software for Higher Education. They were previously involved in development of library management software and a [[Semantic Web]] application platform. In 2005 Talis was voted one of the top [[Information and Communications Technology|ICT]] Employers in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.computingcareers.co.uk/top-it-employers/talis| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070306060612/http://www.computingcareers.co.uk/top-it-employers/talis| dead-url=yes| archive-date=2007-03-06| title=Computing Careers| accessdate=2008-03-13| df=}}</ref>
== History ==
In 1969 a number of libraries founded a small co-operative project, based in Birmingham, to provide services that would help the libraries become more efficient. The project was known as the Birmingham Libraries Co-operative Mechanisation Project, or BLCMP, and included the library of the [[University of Birmingham]]. At this time the concept of [[library automation]] was so new that the term ''mechanisation'' was often used in its place.{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}}
BLCMP began a co-operative catalogue of bibliographic data at the start of its work, a database that now contains many millions of records. For this an adaptation of UKMARC coding was used. This shared approach to creating metadata is the forefather of later, Internet-based, community ventures such as [[Internet Movie Database|IMDb]], [[Freebase (database)|Freebase]] and others. But this was back in 1969 when shipping this data around involved printing cards and putting boxes on trucks. More libraries became members of BLCMP, e.g. many of the academic libraries of Manchester and [[Salford, Greater Manchester|Salford]].
BLCMP moved into using microfiche and later [[IBM]] mainframes with dedicated terminals at libraries in the mid-seventies and was one of the first library automation vendors to provide a [[GUI]] on top of [[Microsoft Windows]] to provide a better interface for end-users. The [[integrated library system]] (ILS) was first called Talis after 'The Automated Library And Information System'. Talis became the name of the company during re-structuring<ref>{{cite journal | year = 1999 | title = BLCMP to Become Talis Information Ltd. | journal = Library Systems | volume = 19 | issue = 1 | pages = 4 | issn = 0277-0288 | oclc = 94137446}}</ref> and the ILS became known as Alto. In 1995 Talis was the first library systems vendor to produce a web-enabled public access catalogue.
During the first decade of the 3rd millennium, much of Talis's work focused on the transition of information to the web, specifically the [[Semantic Web]], and Talis has led much of the debate about how [[Web 2.0]] attitudes affect traditional libraries.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Miller | first = Paul |date=October 2005 | title = Web 2.0: Building the New Library | journal = Ariadne | issue = 19 | url = http://www.ariadne.ac.uk/issue45/miller/ | accessdate = 2008-03-13}}</ref> Alongside semantic web developments Talis launched Talis Education Ltd, a business focused on products in Higher Education learning, and Kasabi, a data marketplace.
In March 2011 Talis sold its library management division to [[Capita Group]]. The division was sold for a reported £18.5 million plus a further £2.5 million depending on the company’s profitability in the following financial year.<ref>[http://www.information-age.com/channels/information-management/news/1607743/capita-acquires-uk-semantic-web-trailblazer-talis.thtml]</ref> The company moved its headquarters from [[Solihull]] to central [[Birmingham]].
Following the sale of its library management business Talis experimented with a semantic web and data marketplace business alongside the rapidly establishing education business. A tough economic climate required Talis to focus its investment, therefore they announced in July 2012 that investment in the semantic web and data marketplace areas would cease. All efforts are now concentrated on the education business.
Talis Aspire, the company's enterprise teaching and learning platform, is now in use by over 1 million students at 93 universities across 8 countries, including over 65% of all UK universities.
Talis was acquired by [[SAGE Publications]] in 2018.<ref>{{cite news |title=SAGE buys technology company Talis |first=Benedicte |last=Page |url= https://www.thebookseller.com/news/sage-buys-technology-company-talis-847456 |newspaper=The Bookseller |date=16 August 2018 |accessdate=17 August 2018}}</ref>
==See also==
* [[Library 2.0]]
==References==
{{reflist}}
==Further reading== * Stubley, P. (1988). ''BLCMP: a guide for librarians and systems managers''. Aldershot, Hants, England: Gower. {{ISBN|978-0-566-05512-6}} * Birmingham; Buckle, David, & BLCMP. (1974). ''Birmingham libraries co-operative mechanisation project: research and development programme, January 1969 to March 1975 : a background paper''. * Birmingham Libraries Co-operative Mechanisation Project, & Buckle, D. G. R. (1976). ''Birmingham Libraries Co-operative Mechanisation Project final report''. Birmingham: BLCMP. (David Buckle became the first manager of BLCMP.)
==External links== * [http://www.talis.com/ Talis Group Ltd.]—company homepage

revision.text:
{{original research|date=January 2015}} {{unreferenced|date=January 2015}} A '''University College Entrance Program''' (UCEP) is an education program in Canada, designed for adults who were unable to successfully complete [[Grade 12]] level [[Course (education)|course]]s, but wish to go into a [[Higher education|post secondary education]]. Many schools offer such a program, which allows a student to gain the necessary prerequisite courses.
UCEP programs helps students get the [[matriculation|matriculation courses]] they need to go on to [[college]] and [[university]] study, giving them the skills, experience and knowledge that are essential for post-secondary success. Students may also enjoy [[field trip]]s, [[theater|theatre productions]], and exposure to different area colleges and universities to become familiar with post-secondary education.
Similarly, UCEP students may receive individualized counseling support to help them work through any barriers to reaching their academic potential. Often, this means overcoming obstacles that prevented these individuals from completing their Grade 12 level courses in the first place.
==External links== Schools:
[[Category:Education in Canada]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=June 2016}} {{use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} {{infobox university | name = Webster University Ghana Campus | image = Webster University Ghana.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = Webster University Ghana's current campus located at East Legon | motto = | motto_lang = | mottoeng = | type = [[Private university|Private]], four-year | established = {{start date and age|2013|paren=yes}} | parent = [[Webster University]]
[[St. Louis]], [[Missouri]],
United States | affiliation = | academic_affiliation = | endowment = | budget = | president = Elizabeth (Beth) J. Stroble | provost = Dr. Julian Z. Schuster | director = Christa Sanders | academic_staff = | administrative_staff = | students = | undergrad = | postgrad = | doctoral = | city = [[Luanda Close, Lagos Avenue, East Legon, Accra]] | province = [[Greater Accra Region]] | country = [[Ghana]] | coor = | campus = | colors = Navy, Gold, and White | nickname = Gorloks | mascot = [[Gorlok]] | language = | sports = | athletics_nickname = | sporting_affiliations = | website = {{URL|webster.edu/ghana}} | logo = Webster University Ghana Logo.png | logo_size = | logo_alt = Webster University Ghana Logo }} '''Webster University Ghana Campus''' is a [[private university]] in [[Accra]], [[Ghana]]. It is the Ghanaian campus of [[Webster University]], based in [[St. Louis]], [[Missouri]], United States. As a member of the Webster University Network, Webster Ghana students have the option of studying abroad at any of Webster's campuses located in eight different countries. Webster has campuses in Austria, China, Vienna, Switzerland, Thailand, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom and the USA. ==History and parent institution== Founded in 2013, Webster Ghana is the Webster University's first campus in Africa. The parent institution, Webster University, operates as an independent, non-denominational university with more than 100 campus locations around the world, including [[Webster University Thailand]], [[Webster University Vienna]], [[Regent's American College London]], [[Webster Leiden|Webster University Leiden]], Webster University Ghana, [[Webster University Geneva]], and Webster University St. Louis. Webster University offers undergraduate and graduate programs in a wide array of disciplines, including the liberal arts, fine and performing arts, teacher education, business, management and media communications. Not all of these degrees are offered at all campuses[http://webster.edu/academics/ "Webster University Academic Programs"]. Retrieved 28 November 2013. ==Academics== Webster University Ghana Campus is accredited by the U.S. [[Higher Learning Commission]] (via the accreditation of Webster University in the state of Missouri)[http://www.ncahlc.org/component/com_directory/Action,ShowBasic/Itemid,192/instid,1474] [[Higher Learning Commission]]. Retrieved 30 April 2013. and by the Ghanaian [[National Accreditation Board (Ghana)|National Accreditation Board]].{{dead link|date=June 2016}} [http://www.nab.gov.gh/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=332:webster-university-ghana&catid=60:private-tertiary-institutions-offering-degree-prog&Itemid=185]. Retrieved 9 January 2014. ==Undergraduate programs== [[File:Webster University Ghana Undergraduates.jpg|thumb|Webster Ghana's undergraduate students interacting]] Webster University Ghana offers undergraduate degrees in:{{Cite web|url=http://www.webster.edu/ghana |title=Programs {{!}} Webster University Ghana |website=www.webster.edu/ghana|access-date=2016-08-16}} * BA International Relations * BA Management * BA Media Communications * BS Computer Science * BS Finance * BA Psychology ==Graduate programs== Webster University Ghana graduate programs are:{{Cite web|url=http://www.webster.edu/ghana |title=Programs {{!}} Webster University Ghana |website=www.webster.edu/ghana|access-date=2016-08-16}} * MA International Relation * [[Master of Business Administration]]. ==Global perspective== ===Webster Worldwide=== As a member of the Webster University Network, Webster Ghana students have the option of [[study abroad in the United States|studying abroad]] at any of Webster's campuses located in eight different countries. Webster has campuses in Austria, China, Vienna, [[Webster University Geneva|Switzerland]], [[Webster University Thailand|Thailand]], the Netherlands, the United Kingdom and the USA.{{cite web|title=Webster Worldwide|url=http://www.webster.edu/worldwide/|work=Webster University Vienna}} As one university system, the international connections Webster has worldwide provides an easy path for their students to study abroad. Students who choose to study abroad have the security of all courses transferring, plus the benefit of choosing a flexible length of stay of between eight weeks to over a year within the same university. ===International locations=== In addition to Webster Ghana, Webster University maintains 9 campus locations around the world, including: [[File:Webster Ghana Staff.jpg|thumb|Webster University Ghana Staff]] * [[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]] - [[Webster University Thailand]] * [[Cha-am]]/[[Hua Hin]], [[Thailand]] - [[Webster University Thailand]] * [[Chengdu]], [[China]] - Webster China * [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]] - [[Webster University Geneva]] Website [http://www.webster.ch] * [[Leiden]], [[Netherlands]] - Webster [[Leiden]] Website [http://www.webster.nl] * [[London]], [[England]] - [[Webster Graduate School]] at [[Regent's College]] * [[Shanghai]], [[China]] - Webster China * [[Shenzhen]], [[China]] - Webster China * [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] - [[Webster University Vienna]] ==See also== {{portal|Ghana|University}} * [[Education in Ghana]] * [[List of universities in Ghana]] * [[List of Webster University alumni]] * [[List of Webster University campus locations]] {{clear}} ==External links== * {{URL|webster.edu/ghana}}, the official website of Webster University Ghana Campus ==References== {{reflist}} {{Ghana universities|state=collapsed}} {{coord missing|Ghana}} [[Category:2013 establishments in Ghana]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 2013]] [[Category:Private universities and colleges]] [[Category:Satellite campuses]] [[Category:Education in Accra]] [[Category:Universities in Ghana]] [[Category:Webster University]]
